Borrower

People’s Republic of Bangladesh.

Project Description

The Project includes three components:

Part  A:  Construction  of  230  kilovolt  (kV)  transmission  lines
and substations around Dhaka;

Part  B(i):  Upgrading  and  expansion  of  the  distribution
system in rural areas around Dhaka.

Part  B(ii):  Upgrading  and  expansion  of  the  distribution
system in Gulshan distribution circle of Dhaka city; and

Part  B(iii):  Upgrading  and  expansion  of  the  distribution
system in the rest of Dhaka city.

Part  C:  Preparatory  work  for  a  training  and  management
development institute.

Economic Growth.

Category  B.  An  initial  environmental  examination  was
undertaken and its summary is a core appendix.

The  Project  furthers  the  ongoing  power  sector  reforms  to
(i)  improve  governance,  (ii)  build  long-term  institutional
capacity, (iii) improve efficiencies, and (iv) facilitate private
sector participation.

The  Project  objectives  are  to  (i)  enable  evacuation  and
economic  utilization  of  the  power  generated  from  the
contracted  Build-Own-Operate/Build-Own-Transfer  (BOO/
BOT)  Projects;  (ii)  reduce  losses  and  improve  reliability  of
the  existing  transmission  and  distribution  system  in  the
Dhaka area; and (iii) initiate preparatory works for a training

  I submit for your approval the following Report and  Recommendation on  two  proposed

1.
loans to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the Dhaka Power System Upgrade Project.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL

II. 

INTRODUCTION

2.
The  Bangladesh  power  sector  performed  poorly  through  the  late  1980s,  and  early
1990s. The major sector  constraints  were  (i)  lack  of  institutional  capability;  (ii)  unavailability  of
long-term domestic capital for financing investments; (iii) limited foreign exchange debt service
capability  of  the  economy;  (iv)  poor  management  systems  and  procedures;  (v)  low  employee
commitment;  and  (vi)  institutional  weaknesses  in  banking,  law  enforcement,  and  judicial
processes, which are external to the sector but are essential for its proper functioning.

3.
  In  1994,  the  Government  of  Bangladesh  (the  Government)  adopted  a  paper  titled
"Power Sector Reforms in Bangladesh" (PSRB)  which  was formulated  in  consultation  with the
major power sector funding agencies1. The PSRB outlines  the  reform process  proposed  to be
followed  by  the  Government  to  gradually  remove  sector  constraints  by  improving  sector  and
corporate  governance,  introducing  competition  and  facilitating  public-private  partnerships.
Reform of the external environment was to be introduced through targeted interventions in the
power sector.

4.
In accordance with the PSRB, the power sector in Bangladesh has been undergoing a
gradual  structural  change.  The  funding  agencies  have  been  supporting  this  change  through
technical  assistance  (TA)  for  planning  and  institutional  strengthening,  as  well  as  capital  for
system expansion, in line with the principle of reform-linked assistance. The proposed Project,
which  is  the  third  assistance  provided  by  ADB  in  support  of  the  reform  process,  is  a  part  of
ADB’s 1999 country assistance program for Bangladesh. The Project is an integral part  of  the
least-cost  development  plan  for  the  power  sector,  and  is  accorded  high  priority  by  the
Government.  The  Project  was  appraised  in  May  1999.2      Appendix  1  provides  the  project
framework.

A.

Sector Description

III.

BACKGROUND

5.
The power sector is organized under the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources. The
the  Ministry,  wholly  owns  and supervises  the  Bangladesh  Power
Government,  through 
Development Board (BPDB), Dhaka Electricity Supply Authority (DESA), and Rural Electrification
Board (REB), which are its three executing agencies (EAs) in the sector. Until FY1998, BPDB was
responsible for all generation and most of the transmission in the country, and also for distribution
in district towns, municipalities, and some rural areas, while DESA was responsible for distribution
in Dhaka, the capital. Electricity distribution  in  most  of the  rural areas  is the  responsibility of the
54 rural  electric  cooperatives,  the  Palli  Bidyut  Samities  (PBSs),  which  are  organized,  initially

PBSs has been much better than that of BPDB or DESA (Table 1).

6.
Bangladesh’s  annual  per  capita  electricity  consumption  of  70  kilowatt-hours  (kWh)  in
FY1998  was  the  third  lowest  among  ADB's  developing  member  countries  after  Nepal  and
Cambodia.4  Despite  intensive  efforts  to  increase  coverage,  only  about  18  percent  of  the
population has access to electricity.5  Consumption  of electricity  increased at an average annual
rate of 8.5  percent from FY1994 to FY1999, with major increases in industrial and residential use.
The ADB-financed Power System  Master Plan  (PSMP)  study  6   assessed    that  the  demand  for
electricity will increase by about 8 percent per year; and the peak demand will be about 3,500 MW
by FY2000, although this looks extremely unlikely given the supply constraints in the sector. The
current installed capacity is 3,611 MW, of which about 2,700 MW is available, the rest being shut
down for rehabilitation or major maintenance.

Inadequate supply of electricity is a major constraint to economic growth. During FY1999,
7.
load-shedding ranging from 16 to 774 MW, was resorted to on 335 days for a total duration of
1,690 hours.  Inadequate gas  supply  was partly  responsible for  lower power generation during
the  year.  Although  the  gas  supply  situation  has  improved,  load-shedding  will  continue  until
substantial  new  generation  capacity  is  added  to  the  system  to  (i)  replace  very  old  power
stations,  (ii)  allow  for  routine  preventive  maintenance  by  creating  a  reserve  margin,  and
(iii) meet  the  increased  demand.  Erratic  power  supply  has  tended  to  increase  consumers'

unwillingness  to  pay  their  bills.  This  in  turn  has  led  to  shortages  of  funds  for  maintenance  and
further aggravated the situation.

8.
Since  Bangladesh's  terrain  is  flat,  hydropower  potential  is  limited.  The  Jamuna-Padma-
Meghna river system, which runs north to south, divides the country in two. The country's entire
proven  recoverable  reserves  of  oil  (including  condensate),  estimated  at  59 million  barrels,  and
natural gas, estimated at 15 trillion cubic feet, are located on the eastern side of the river system.
The  limited  hydropower  potential  is  also  in  the  eastern  part  of  the  country.  The  west  has  no
developed commercial sources of energy. Coal reserves, which are located in the northwest, are
deep beneath the surface and difficult to develop. Only one potential mine with a limited output of
about 1 million tons per annum is being developed with external assistance. Consequently, of the
country's total installed generation capacity of 3,611 MW, only about 590 MW (fueled by diesel oil
and heavy fuel oil), is  in  the  west.  Of the 3,021  MW  in the east, 2,786  MW is based on natural
gas,  the  country's  primary  commercial  fuel,  and  235  MW  is  hydropower.  In  terms  of  energy
generated, about 90 percent of the total in FY1999 was from gas-fired power plants.

9.
In  FY1998,  BPDB's  average  retail  tariff  for  its  ultimate  consumers  was  Tk2.67/kWh
($0.055/kWh),  DESA's  was  Tk2.63/kWh  ($0.052/kWh),  and  PBS's  Tk3.30/kWh  ($0.07/kWh),
leading  to  a  weighted  average  tariff  of  Tk.2.76/kWh  ($0.058/kWh),  as  compared  with  the
estimated  long  run  marginal  cost  (LRMC)  supply  of  Tk3.86/kWh  ($0.078/kWh).  The  LRMC  will,
however, decline sharply by FY2002 due to the lower costs of production from private sector IPPs.
Retail  tariffs  are  being  adjusted  semi-annually  to  take  into  account  fluctuations  in  foreign
exchange rates and fuel costs in particular the price of natural gas.

B.

Government  Policies and Plans

The  PSRB  envisions  a  power  sector  structure  based  on  (i) the separation  of  sector
10.
regulation  and  operation;  (ii)  autonomy  and  commercial  orientation  of  the  sector  entities;
(iii) unbundling  of  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution;  and  (iv) increased  private  sector
participation. A new regulatory authority would be responsible for (i) setting electricity tariffs and
determining  the  corresponding performance norms;  (ii)  collecting,  verifying,  and  disseminating
sector  statistics;  (iii)  reviewing  and  approving  long-term  power  planning;  (iv)  creating  and
maintaining  a  nondiscriminatory  and  commercial  business  environment  in  the  sector;  and  (v)
adjudicating disputes between sector entities. While the transmission segment would remain in
the  public  sector,  generation  and  distribution  assets  would  have  both  public  and  private
ownership. The objective is  to  eliminate  monopolies and  instill  competition  in order to achieve
commercial discipline and good customer service.

After  initiation  of  reforms  in  1994,  the  organizational  setup  of  the  sector  changed.  In
11.
1994, all generation  was  with BPDB;  today  there  are  several  public-private and private  sector
entities  licensed  to  construct  and  operate  power-generating  facilities.  The  first  private  barge-
mounted  power  station  started  operation  in  December  1998.  RPC’s  first  gas  turbine  at  its
Mymensingh site was commissioned on 20 November 1999.7 Others, under varying degrees of
construction, are three barge-mounted power stations totaling about 300 MW, the IPP stations
at Meghnaghat (450 MW) 8 and Haripur (360 MW), and the 100 MW expansion at Baghabari.

Good governance, at the sector and corporate levels, is emphasized in the PSRB. At the
12.
sector level, governance is to be improved through predictability (long-term planning, codification
of  rules  and  regulations,  and  independence  of  regulatory  processes),  transparency  (systematic

8

 4

dissemination  of  relevant  sector  information,  public  hearings,  and  discussions  on  issues  before
they are decided) and accountability (cause-effect structure of incentives). At the corporate level,
governance is to be enhanced through corporatization, independence of boards of directors from
the  Government,  defined  delegation  of  powers  to  staff,  computerized  management  information
systems, and commercialization of activities.

13.
The Government    realizes  that  the  investment  requirements  for  the  power  sector  during
the  next  decade,  estimated  at  about  $6.6  billion,  exceed  the  resources  available  in  the  public
sector and could crowd out investment in other key sectors. Therefore, the Government has taken
a policy decision to invite the private sector to participate in sector development. The Government
has  made  substantial  efforts  to  streamline  administrative  and  commercial  procedures  and  the
private sector has responded positively in its participation. The Government, with the assistance
of ADB, and the World Bank, has successfully solicited private sector participation in generation.
To streamline the legislative basis for the sector’s restructuring and regulation, and to enable the
establishment of an independent regulatory authority, the Government is in the process of drafting
a new electricity reform act and is expected to introduce it to Parliament by December 1999. An
ADB  TA  will  help  draft  power  sector  regulations  to  be  administered  by  the  new  regulatory
authority.9  This will  enable depoliticization of the tariff setting and  licensing procedures,  making
the sector’s operations more transparent.

C.

External Assistance to the Sector

14.
Investment in the power sector during the last decade totaled $3,541 million. The major
sources  of  external  funding  have  been  the  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  France,  Kreditanstalt  für
Wiederaufbau  (KfW),  Overseas  Economic  Cooperation  Fund  (OECF)10,  Department  For
International  Development  (DFID),  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development
(USAID), Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC),  People’s  Republic of  China,
and  the  Russia  Federation.  Other  sources  include  the  Islamic  Development  Bank;  the  Kuwait
Fund  for  Arab  Economic  Development;  Saudi  Fund  for  Development;  Canadian  International
International
Development  Agency;  United  Nations’  Development  Program,  Swedish 
Development  Cooperation  Agency;  Belgium,  Danish  International  Development  Assistance;
and Department for International Development Cooperation Finland.  A summary of the external
assistance to the sector,  detailing the Bank's assistance, is given in Appendix 2.

15. While  the  ADB  has  supported  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution  in  urban  areas,
OECF  has  focused  on  generation  and  rural  electrification  projects.  DFID  has  financed
transmission and distribution in the Dhaka area in the past and is providing assistance to develop
renewable energy sources.  USAID  has  been  instrumental  in  establishing  and  funding  REB  and
the first PBSs, and continues to provide technical support to REB and the PBSs. KfW supported
generating  capacity  augmentation  and  transmission  reinforcement  projects.  Other  aid  agencies
financed  generation  projects,  and  France  and  OPEC  have  financed  some  transmission  and
distribution projects as  well.  The World Bank earlier supported distribution  in  smaller  towns  and
rural areas. However, following initiation of the reforms, it has not provided any assistance to the
sector other than TA for soliciting private sector participation and establishing the Power Cell. It is
currently in the process of formulating a $600 million adjustable program lending modality loan to
the power sector.

 D.

Lessons Learned

1.

Contextual Issues

5

16.
The ADB has extensively supported the sector over the last 23 years. From its role as a
project financier in the 1970s, ADB provided funds as well as technical advice in the 1980s. Since
the initiation of the PSRB in 1994, ADB has provided policy advice to the Government on PSRB
implementation  as  well  as  funds  to  help  achieve  the  least  cost  expansion  program.  During  this
involvement, ADB has learned the following lessons.

17.
Overall,  macroeconomic/political  issues  of  the  country  have  a  significant  bearing  on  the
sector's  performance  as  well  as  its  ability  to  reform.  Political  unrest,  labor  militancy,  peace  and
security  enforcement,  speed  and  quality  of  the  judicial  processes,  and  ability  of  the  education
system to provide the skilled labor, all affect the sector's performance, although there is very little
that  the  sector  by  itself  can  do  to  systematically  address  these  problems.  Power  sector
development  can  only  proceed  in  tandem  with  reforms  in  the  rest  of  the  economy  and  the
sociopolitical  regime,  and  to  the  level  permitted  by  these  external  constraints.  Forcing  reforms
beyond this point becomes dysfunctional and may even jeopardize the entire reform process.

18.
Delegation of powers from the Government to the management of the utilities and from the
management to the staff is very limited, and despite efforts by ADB and other funding agencies,
has  not  been  sufficiently  enhanced.  The  entities  are  also  restricted  by  the  Government's
personnel and wage policies, which inhibit the  recruitment and  retention of  competent staff, and
the retrenchment or dismissal of excess or nonperforming staff. Tariffs are based more on political
considerations than on economic factors. The losses incurred by the utilities are compensated for
by  long-term,  low  interest  loans  from  the  Government;  this  is  detrimental  to  the  efficiency  and
financial  health  of  the  utilities.  Losses  incurred  by  the  utilities  are  also  compensated  for  by
converting Government debt to equity. Currently BPDB’s debt-equity ratio stands at 40:60. These
factors clearly underscore the limited extent of improvements that can be made to the utilities in
their  present  form.  It  is  therefore  essential  that  new  sector  entities  be  created  that  are  not
subjected  to  the  organizational  limitations  of  BPDB  and  DESA,  and  that  there  be  an  overall
environment of commercialization in the sector. Further, there is a need to distance the authority
for effecting tariff changes from the Government and depoliticize it.

19.
Fundamental changes in infrastructure sectors take time to implement even in developed
countries. In developing countries, change is more difficult to implement, and, therefore, requires
a more gradual approach. Speeding up reforms is functional only if the change is comprehensive.
For  example,  increasing  tariffs  too  rapidly  may  help  sector  finances  but  often  undermines  the
reform  objectives  by  penalizing  the  good  consumer  if  the  utilities  collect  only  from  a  low
percentage  of  consumers.  Affordability  is  also  a  factor.  Rapid  tariff  increases  can  drive  up  the
costs  of  electricity,  making  it  unaffordable  to  the  poorer  consumers,  whereas  more  gradual
increases allow time for managing their effects.

2.

Compliance of Reform Actions Under Earlier Bank Loans

The  ADB’s  Eighth  Power  Project  will  close  in  December  1999  and  the  Rural
20.
Electrification Project is expected to be completed early next year. All structural reform-related
conditionalities stipulated in these loans were met. The status of fulfillment of the restructuring
conditionalities stipulated under the Bank’s ongoing Ninth Power Project is as follows:

(i) 

Rationalization of DESA’s Boundaries. As per the agreement, DESA was to have
handed  over  its  rural  areas  to  the  PBSs  by  March  1998.    The  law  defining
DESA’s  boundaries  was  amended  on  19  April  1998.  The  Gazaria  area  was

handed  over  to  the  PBSs  in  March  1998.  The  hand  over  of  the  Savar,
Narshingdi,  and  Manikganj  areas  was  completed  in  September  1998.  The
balance was partially handed over in September and October 1999 with the last
transfer scheduled for December 1999. This rationalization has already improved
performance and reduced distribution losses by about 5 percent.

Handover of Transmission Assets to PGCB. BPDB was to have handed over the
Comilla (North) and Haripur 230 kilovolt (kV) substations and about 45 kilometers
(km)  of  230  kV  transmission  lines  by  June  1998.  However,  there  was  a  delay
because  of  a  debate  on  whether  asset  transfers  should  be  gradual  or
simultaneous.  The  Government,  earlier  attempted  to  have  all  the  assets
simultaneously  transferred  in  February-March  1998.  The  excessive  financial,
administrative,  and  personnel  problems  faced  by  BPDB  and  PGCB  made  this
transfer impossible. The Government then decided in September 1998, that the
transfers  would  be  gradual  with  the  Ninth  Power-  related  assets  transferred  in
March  1999.  The  assets  pertaining  to  the  Bank’s  Ninth  Power  Project  were
legally  transferred  on  31 March  1999,  and  physical  transfer  was  completed  on
13 October  1999.  This  transfer  has  started  the  process  of  segregating  the
subsectors.

Handover  of  DESA’s  Mirpur  Assets  to  DESCO.  This  was  completed  on
24 September  1998  with  a  delay  of  four  months,  and  marks  the  start  of  the
corporatization process of the distribution subsector.

Award  of  Contract  for  the  Meghnaghat  Project.  This  activity  was  to  have  been
completed  by  June  1998.  However,  the  selection  of  sponsors  and  award  of
contract  for  the  Meghnaghat  Power  Project  was  delayed  by  over  a  year.  All
project contracts were signed on 29 July 1999.

Liquidation of Government dues to BPDB and  DESA.  Arrangements have been
made for payment of Tk750 million in three tranches to liquidate  BPDB arrears.
The  first  tranche  of  Tk250  million  was  paid,  and  budgetary  provision  made  for
payment  of  the  second  tranche  in  FY1999.  Similar  arrangements  are  being
explored for DESA. This is an ongoing activity and is expected to be completed
by the end of FY2001.

Revision of Retail Tariffs.   As  per  the  agreement  between  the Government and
the  ADB,  retail  tariffs  are  reviewed  and  automatically  adjusted  for  variations  in
fuel  costs  and  foreign  exchange  value  of  the  taka  every  six  months,  as  per  a
formula.  Retail  tariffs  have  been  reviewed  and  adjusted  (when  necessary)  in
March  and  September  of  each  year  except  in  1999  when  partial  adjustments
were  announced  in  July  because  the  introduction  of  the  value  added  tax  on  all
commodities and services. This tax affected retail electricity tariffs. In its review of
September 1999,  the Government however,  adjusted  retail  tariffs  and  made  up
the shortfall of the March 1999 review.

The fulfillment of  conditions related to  restructuring  has been delayed  in  some  cases  by
21.
over a year. Nevertheless, the Government must be complimented on its determination to follow
through  with  these  politically  difficult  and  sensitive  actions.  Some  have  led  to  law  and  order
problems  that  the  Government  had  to  tackle  firmly.  Since  the  commencement  of  the  reform
program in 1994, the Government has always delivered on the conditionalities it has agreed upon
with  ADB  as  part  of  the  process  of  power  sector  reforms.  This  gives  ADB  confidence  that
necessary  actions  will  be  taken  by  the  Government  and  that  it  will  determinedly  pursue  the
reforms in the future.

 7

22.
The  political  situation  in  the  last  few  years  has  significantly  affected  the  collection
operations  of  both  BPDB  and  DESA  since  many  commercial  establishments,  including  banks,
were  closed  for  prolonged  periods  and  those  that  were  open  functioned  with  minimal  services.
DESA was particularly hard hit since Dhaka, as the capital city, was the center of the unrest, and
normal  life  in  the  city  was disrupted for longer periods than  in  other  towns.  During  FY1998,  the
collection to generation ratio of BPDB and collection to import ratio of DESA were 64.03 percent
and  57.98 percent  respectively.  These  are  far  below  the  targets  of  75 percent  for  BPDB  and
70 percent for DESA, and worse than the performance of FY1997. Performance of  BPDB and
DESA has also been affected by the constant changing of senior staff and low  morale of  staff
caused  by  the  knowledge  that  other  organizations  will  replace  BPDB  and  DESA  in  the  near
future.  On  the  other  hand  the  performance  of  the  seven  PBSs  supported  by  the  ADB  in  the
Rural  Electrification  Project    has  been  very  good  with  an  average  collection  to  import  ratio  of
83.3 percent.

E.

ADB's Sector Strategy

23.
The ADB recognizes that (i) the substantial external assistance provided to the  sector  in
the  past  has  induced  a  tendency  in  the  sector  agencies  to  depend  on  external  assistance  for
funding,  (ii)  recovery  and  development  must  be  led  from  within  the  sector,  and  (iii)  the
Government and all major aid agencies must realign their individual strategies to emphasize this
objective.  In  consultation  with  the  Government  and  the  other  funding  agencies  involved  in  the
sector,  ADB has developed a medium-term plan to improve the power sector (Appendix 3). The
strategy  consists  of  (i) changes 
through  corporatization,
commercialization,  and  increasing  private  sector  participation;  (ii) institutional  improvements  in
BPDB  and  DESA  through  introduction  of  modern  management  practices;  (iii)  creation  of  new
sector  agencies  that  could  serve  as  role  models  for  the  sector;  (iv)  enlarging  the  scope  of  the
PBSs; and (v) strengthening the long-term planning and regulatory processes in the sector.  The
proposed Project addresses items (i), (iii),  and (iv) of this strategy. Item (ii) is an ongoing process
and item (v) has partially been addressed through the Power Sector Master Plan, the creation of
the Power Cell, and ADB's TA for support to the Energy Regulatory Authority.

the  business  environment

F.

Policy Dialogue

The ADB, World Bank, OECF,  DFID,  USAID,  and  KfW have  been  involved  in  a  policy
24.
dialogue  with  the Government about  issues  in  the  power  sector,  with  ADB  playing  the  role  of
coordinator. The ADB has played a major role in drawing up the reform assistance strategy of
the funding agencies, and in addition, has organized and coordinated aid coordination meetings
for the power sector in 1992, 1994, 1995, and 1996, and for the power and natural gas sectors
in 1997 and 1998. ADB-led aid coordination meetings in December 1992, December 1994, and
September 1995  contributed to  the formulation of reforms and the  identification of  reform-linked
projects  in  the  sector.  The  ADB  also  provided  TAs  to  review  electricity  legislation,11  prepare  a
power system master plan,12 upgrade the financial management of BPDB and DESA, 13 solicit for
private sector implementation of the  Meghnaghat Project14  and  corporatize the Ashuganj Power
Station of BPDB.  15 The Bank has been instrumental  in assisting  the Government  to draw up a
plan for the planned transformation of the sector, and the creation of new sector entities.

25.
The medium-term goals of the policy dialogue with the Government up to 2005 and the
results achieved so far are summarized at Appendix 3. Generation is no longer a monopoly, and
has  sufficient  private  sector  interest;  the  public  sector  stations  are  starting  to  be  corporatized
and commercialized. A start has been made in the process of segregating and corporatizing the
transmission  function.  Distribution  is  being  corporatized  in  the  Dhaka  area,  and  the  private
sector PBSs have  increased  their  share of  sales  from  13  percent  in  FY1993  to  22  percent  in
FY1999.  Average  retail  power  tariffs  were  increased  by  a  total  of  about  15  percent  (in
September  and  December  1996)  and  an interim  formula  for  semiannual  adjustment  of  retail
power  tariffs  to  take  into  account  fluctuations  in  fuel  costs  and  foreign  exchange  rates  was
successfully implemented. 16 On the regulatory side, work has progressed through the creation
of the Power Cell, which is mandated to plan and execute reform-related activities and act as a
quasi-regulator  until  the statutory  regulator  is  appointed,  and  preparatory  studies  on  new
legislation, sector structure, and tariff framework have been completed. The draft Electricity and
Regulatory Commission Act, 17 which will form the legal basis for power sector reform, is under
review by the cabinet  and is expected to be introduced in Parliament by December 1999.

26.
The funding agencies hold  a coordination  meeting every  year  to  review  sector policies
and  achievements.  ADB  missions  have  explained  the  rationale  behind  the  Project  in  several
meetings.  The  funding  agencies  all  support  the  Project  itself  but  do  not  agree  on  all  issues.
While  the  World  Bank  is  of  the  opinion  that  all  BPDB  generation  plants  should  be  privatized
immediately,  this  view  is  not  supported  by  ADB,  OECF,  and  KfW,  the  agencies  involved  in
providing funding for the power stations. They believe that corporatization and establishment of
a commercial structure for the sector should precede any attempt at privatization. In any case,
there is not enough private capital available in Bangladesh to purchase these assets and such a
sale, if it fails, could affect successful private sector participation in other areas of the sector. All
funding  agencies,  however,  agree  that  there  is  a  limit  to  the  country's  foreign  investment
absorption  capability.  Too  rapid  an  external  investment  rate  in  fixed  assets  would  create  a
squeeze in the local currency markets when repatriating debt servicing and profits.

All  funding  agencies  consider  distribution  subsector  reform  to  be  a  priority  as  this
27.
subsector  collects  the  entire  revenues  of  the  sector.  The  ADB  has  assumed  responsibility  for
assisting  with  reforms  in  the  Dhaka  area  and  the  World  Bank  for  areas  outside  of  Dhaka.
Expansion  of  REB/PBS  activities  has  been  supported  by  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  OECF,  and
USAID.

28.
DFID  is  concerned  about  DESA’s  performance  being  much below  that targeted  by  the
funding  agencies.  Hence  it  is  of  the  opinion  that  new  assistance  should  not  be  provided  to
DESA until it achieves the targeted performance levels. ADB believes that the ultimate objective
is to improve sector efficiencies without major disruptions in electricity service and without any
political embarrassment to the  Government,  which could dilute  its  commitment  to  reform.  The
ADB’s operation in the Dhaka area and its support to DESA must also be viewed as a holding
operation to enable other reforms to be initiated in the sector. Since DESA has failed to perform,
DESCO  was  created;  it  will  gradually  take  over  DESA's  assets,  make  the  necessary
improvements  and  has  the  potential  to  be  privatized.  DESA’s  market  share  is  being  reduced
progressively  by  transferring  parts  of  its  distribution  territory  to  DESCO  and    the  PBSs.  In  a
sense,  therefore  ADB  is  investing  in  a  DESCO  of  the  future  when  it  invests  in  present  day
DESA.  In  the  interim  period,  DESCO  will  provide  DESA  with  competition,  which  will  aid

A.

Rationale

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

30.
The Project is a continuation of the long-term strategy of the Government and ADB for
power sector reform. The rationale for the choice of the reform components of the Project is as
follows.

1.

Generation

The private sector has the potential to add about 1,400 MW of capacity over the next five
31.
years.  This  is 39  percent of  the  current  installed capacity  of  3,611  MW  and  68 percent  of  the
currently  available  capacity  of  about  2,400  MW.  Thus  there  is  a  need  to  take  stock  of  the
situation before further IPP capacity is committed. The Government has guaranteed conversion
of  foreign  exchange  under  the  several  implementation  agreements  that  were  signed,  or
committed to be signed, with the private sector IPPs; the amount under guarantee represents a
significant portion of its total foreign exchange reserves. The total capacity of the new projects,
including  additional  peaking  power  stations  as  required,  would  be  adequate  to  fulfill  the
requirements of the country until 2005 at the current rate of load  growth.

the  generating 

Corporatization  of 

facilities  presently  under  BPDB  and 

32.
their
commercialization  has  commenced.  Since economic  dispatch  routines  will be enforced  by  the
regulator, it is essential that the power stations owned and operated by BPDB be upgraded both
technically and managerially; otherwise, they  risk  being  marginalized  under  the new operating
regime. Given that the present structure and internal procedures of BPDB are not conducive to
rapid absorption of new routines, staffing norms, and internal discipline that would be demanded
of it, a new corporatized subsidiary of BPDB is being created to take over the responsibility of
managing the Ashuganj Power Station. This company will function as another IPP. Funding for
upgrading the Ashuganj Power Station is being considered by KfW and JBIC.

2.

Transmission

33.
For transmission,  priority  investments  include  (i)  the  development of the  National Load
Dispatch  Center,  (ii) the  strengthening  of  the  primary  transmission  system  in  the  West  Zone,
(iii) the completion of the 230 kV double-circuit ring around Dhaka, and (iv) the completion of the
interconnection from Comilla to Chittagong. The World Bank has  already  indicated  support for
the  National  Load  Dispatch  Center,  and  KfW  for  the  Comilla-Chittagong  interlink  and
components for strengthening the West Zone network.

 10

34. With the assistance extended to PGCB as part of the ADB's Ninth Power Project and the
proposed assistance being considered for it by the World Bank and KfW, completing the 230kV
double-circuit  ring  system  around  Dhaka  is  the  only  remaining  work  of  priority,  since  it  is
essential  for  delivering  adequate  quantities  of  secure  power  to  the  Dhaka  area  and  also  for
evacuation  and  economic  utilization  of  power  from  all  the  BOO/BOT  projects  now  being
contracted.

3.

Distribution

35.
Given the extensive participation of the private sector in generation projects, the financial
viability of the power sector will be in jeopardy unless the distribution subsector is strengthened
to ensure offtake of power as well as generate adequate revenues for servicing the investments
in the generation and transmission subsectors. Otherwise, the Government's guarantees to the
IPPs could be called, placing an unacceptable burden on its budgets. The ADB has two options
available; (i) to consolidate its involvement in the Dhaka area, or (ii) to help other major towns
restructure  their  distribution  networks.  Given  (i)  the  precarious  state  of  Dhaka’s  distribution
network  and  the  requirement  for  large  investments  to  upgrade  it;  (ii)  the  preponderance  of
Dhaka as a economic center of Bangladesh; (iii) the considerable work ADB has put in as part
of  its  previous  operations  in  this  area,  which  are  just  beginning  to  show  results;  and  (iv)  the
limitation of ADB’s staff resources, it is appropriate for ADB to continue its support for upgrading
distribution in the Dhaka area.

4.

Institutional Strengthening

36.
The  Bangladesh  power  sector  will  have  to  rapidly  expand  into  the  rural  areas  if  the
current low access rate of electricity is to be speedily improved. This is going to place a major
burden  on  the  human  resources  of  REB  and  the  PBSs.  At  present  REB  has  only  a  small
technical training establishment at Savar near Dhaka, and skeletal managerial training facilities
at its headquarters. This arrangement is inadequate for the future, and REB needs to develop
full  facilities  for  training  and  development  of  PBS  staff.  Hence,  REB  has  requested  ADB's
support  to  strengthen  human  resource  development  activities.  This  training  facility,  when
established, would also be available for use by other sector entities on a cost sharing basis.

37.
Based on the foregoing analysis, it is appropriate for ADB to support  (i) completing  the
230kV ring around Dhaka city; (ii) upgrading of distribution in the Dhaka area; (iii)  establishing
a training and managerial development institute in REB.

B.

Objectives and Scope

38.
The  objectives  of  the  Project  are  to  (i)  enable  evacuation  and  economic  utilization
of the power generated from the BOO/BOT projects now being contracted; (ii) reduce losses  and 
improve  reliability  of  the  existing  transmission  and  distribution  system  in  the  Dhaka  area;  and
(iii) initiate preparatory works for a training and management development institute in REB.

The Special Funds resources loan will have a term of 32 years including a grace period
45.
of  8 years  and  an  interest  charge  of  1.0  percent  per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and
1.5 percent  per  annum  thereafter.  The  Borrower  will  be  the People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh,
and the proceeds will be relent to DESA and REB for  parts  B(i) and  (iii)  and  C of the  Project,
pursuant  to  subsidiary  loan  agreements  with  terms  and  conditions  satisfactory  to  ADB.
Relending terms to DESA will include a repayment period of 20 years, including a 4-year grace
period,  and  an  interest  rate  of  8  percent  per  annum.  For  REB,  relending  terms  will  include  a
repayment period of 30 years including a grace period of 8 years. Interest will be charged at a
rate of 1 percent per annum during the grace period and 3 percent per annum thereafter. The
preferential  relending  terms  allowed  to  REB  are  in  recognition  of  the  noncommercial,  human
resource development nature of its activities.

The OCR loan will be provided  to  the People's  Republic of Bangladesh  with  a 20-year
46.
term, including a grace period of 5 years and at an interest to be determined in accordance with
ADB's pool-based variable lending rate for such loans. It will be utilized to finance Parts A and
B(ii)  of  the  Project.  The  loan  will  be  relent  to  PGCB  and  DESCO  with  a  repayment  period  of
20 years, including a 4-year grace period, and at the same interest rate plus a fee of 1 percent.
The OCR loan will be the first such loan to Bangladesh from the ADB since its reclassification
as a B1  19 country. As such, it represents a substantial hardening of the  ADB’s  support to the

(ii) 

(iii)

organization matters 20.

2.

Implementation Schedule and Performance Review

The  project  implementation  schedule  is  given  in  Appendix  5.  Implementation  has
50.
commenced in September 1999 and will be completed in September 2003. Direct supervision of
subproject  implementation  and  monitoring  of  subproject  operation  performance  will  be  the
responsibility of the EAs and the Government. EAs will provide quarterly progress reports to ADB
on their respective responsibilities, within 30 days of the end of each quarter. The ADB will review
the implementation and operation of the Project based on  these reports and  meet with the EAs
and  the  Government    semiannually  to  discuss  project  progress.  The  ADB  will  also  monitor  the
overall performance of the EAs.

3.

Procurement

51.
Procurement  of  goods  and  services  financed  by  ADB  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance
with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement. For such procurement, bid specifications will be prepared
in  a  manner  to  ensure  maximum  competition  under  international  competitive  bidding.  To
encourage  local  industry,  it  is  proposed  to  permit  the  EAs  to  accord  local  manufacturers
participating  in  international  bids  under  the  project,  price  preference  of  up  to  a  maximum  of
15 percent  as  per  ADB's  scheme  for  such  preferences.  A  list  of  the  major  contract  packages
under the Project with their cost estimates is given in Appendix 6.

with  ADB's  Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.  Outline  terms  of  reference  for  consulting

Advance Procurement Action

53.
All the EAs have sufficient expertise in procuring materials for the works entrusted to them
under the Project and have been allowed to initiate advance procurement action for the goods and

advance procurement action will not in any way commit it to subsequently approve the Project. All
such advance procurement actions will be in accordance with ADB’s  Guidelines for Procurement
and its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants as described in paras 51 and 52 respectively.

6.

Disbursement Procedures

54.
Since  the  disbursements  under  the  Project  will  be  mainly  for  supply  of  goods  and
consulting  services,  ADB's  commitment  and  direct  payment  procedures  will  be  used  for
disbursement purposes.

7. 

Reports,  Accounts,  and Audits

55.
The  EAs  will  prepare  separate  progress  reports  for  their  respective  components  and
submit  them  to  ADB  on  a  quarterly  basis.  The  reports  will  provide  a  narrative  description  of
progress made during the period, changes to the implementation schedule, problems or difficulties
encountered,  the  performance  of  the  project  implementation  consultants,  and  the  work  to  be
carried  out  in  the  upcoming  period.  The  progress  reports  will  also  include  a  summary  financial
account for  the Project. This will  consist of project expenditures during the period, year to date,
and total expenditure to date. The ADB will review the implementation and operation of the Project
based  on  these  reports  and  meet  with  the  EAs  and  the  Government  semiannually  to  discuss
project progress. Project completion reports will be submitted to ADB within six months of project
completion.

The  EAs  will  have  their  annual  financial  statements  and  Project  accounts  audited  by  a
56.
professional  auditing  firm  acceptable  to  ADB.  Unaudited  statements  will  be  furnished  to  ADB
within six  months of the close of  the  financial  year  and  audited  statements  within  three  months
thereafter.

58.

Dhaka Electricity Supply Authority

a. 

Responsibilities

65.
DESA is a statutory authority of the Government created by the Dhaka Electricity Supply
Authority Ordinance of 1990 (Presidential Ordinance No. 6 of 1990). It has the responsibility to
purchase electricity from BPDB at 132 kV and distribute the same to consumers in the  Dhaka
area, other than those areas covered by the PBSs.

 DESA is governed by a board appointed by the Government and comprising a full-time

66.
chairperson and three full-time members.

b.

Organizational Structure

c.

Financial Performance

67.
A summary of DESA's projected financial performance is provided in Table 6. DESA has
been operating since 1991. When established, DESA assumed debt and accounts receivable in
addition  to  assets  transferred  from  BPDB.  Over  the  past  eight  years,  DESA’s  financial
performance  has  been  less  than  satisfactory.  DESA’s  systems  losses  are  well  above  those
normally expected in an efficiently run distribution company, with some districts incurring actual
losses as high as 60 percent. DESA’s collection ratio, which has at times dropped to as low as

gradually  handed  over  all  its  assets  to  DESCO  or  other  successor  companies  by  2002  and
have  ceased  to  exist  in  its  present  form.  Therefore,  although  financial  projections  have  been

4. 

Rural Electrification Board / Palli Bidyut Samities

a. 

Responsibilities

REB  is  an  infrastructure  development  agency  of  the  Government,  created  as  an
68.
autonomous  entity  under  a  Presidential  Ordinance  in  1977  to  implement  the  electrification
program through consumer cooperatives, the PBSs. The creation of this autonomous body was

 18

one  of  the  recommendations  of  the  consulting  firms  that  conducted  feasibility  studies  for  the
Government’s Rural Electrification Program in 1977, which was financed by USAID.

69.
The major functions of REB, as incorporated in its charter, are to (i) establish electricity
generation,  transmission,  and  distribution  systems  in  rural  areas  of  Bangladesh;  (ii)  organize
prospective  consumers  of  electricity  into  formal  and  informal  groups  such  as  societies  and
companies;  (iii)  formulate  bylaws,  for  the  PBSs  and  other  groups  registered  with  REB,  and
determine  the  methods  of  their  operations;  (iv)  advance  funds  for  the  implementation  of
approved schemes, the operation and management of works and services, and construction of
lines for members for electric connections; (v) hand over to the PBSs the completed projects for
operation,  maintenance,  and  management;  (vi)  train  personnel  in  the  management  and
operation  of  REB  and  the  PBSs;  (vii)  develop  standards  for  work,  equipment,  operation,
maintenance,  procurement  and  warehousing,  personnel  and  fiscal  administration,  and  other
aspects  of  management  to  be  followed  by  REB  as  well  as  by  the  PBSs  and  other  groups
registered with REB.

70.
There are 54 PBSs that currently serve about 1.2 million consumers and distribute about
22 percent of the electricity consumed in the country. The responsibilities of a PBS begin when
a distribution scheme is handed over to it for operation and maintenance after construction and
commissioning.  Its  principal  objective  is  to  supply  its  members  and  other  consumers  with
electricity.  Its  functions  include  (i)  distributing  electricity  and  providing  consumer  connections;
(ii) meter  reading,  billing,  and  collection;  (iii)  purchasing  electricity  from  BPDB  and  DESA;
(iv) planning  and  implementing  the  expansion  of  local  distribution  acquiring  and  installing
electrical appliances, and improving system power factors through the installation of capacitors.

b. 

Organizational Structure

71.
REB  is  managed  by  a  Board  consisting  of  a  chairperson  and  three  full-time  board
members (finance, engineer, and PBSs and training). To coordinate with the rural electrification
program  in  their  respective  fields,  four  part-time  Board  members,  represent  BPDB,  the
Bangladesh  Agricultural  Development  Corporation,  the  Bangladesh  Small  and  Cottage
Industries Corporation, and the Bangladesh Rural Development Board.

Each  PBS  is  a  member-owned  autonomous  cooperative,  distributing  electricity  in  its
72.
service area. The initial board of directors of a PBS is selected from local citizens, subject to the
approval of  REB’s board  of  directors. After  appointment, directors  register  the  PBS  with  REB,
which then proceeds to encourage potential consumers  to  become  members of the  PBS.  The
board of directors consists of 10-15 members elected by an annual members’ meeting. Eligibility
to become or remain a director includes being a bona fide member of a PBS and a resident of
its service area. Any person or organization in a PBS's area may become a member of the PBS
following acceptance by the board of directors and payment of a membership application fee of
Tk10. The Board elects a president who functions as its chief representative officer.

c.

Financial Performance

The ultimate owners  and operators of  the  REB-implemented  component  of  the  Project
73.
will  be  the  seven  PBSs  of  Dhaka-1,  Dhaka-2,  Narshingdi-1,  Narshingdi-2,  Manikgonj,
Mymensing-1, and  Munshigonj.  To assess  the financial  position  and  performance  of  Part  B(i),
the  financial  statements  for  the  seven  PBSs  were  consolidated  and  projected  based  on  the
consolidated  position.  A  summary  of  the  consolidated  financial  performance  is  provided  in
Table 7.

 19

74.
The PBSs have the authority to set retail tariffs (with the exception of agriculture tariffs,
which are established by the Government). PBS tariffs tend to be sufficient to cover all operating
costs  and  debt  service  obligations,  and  provide  an  adequate  return  on  equity.  The  PBSs  are
nontaxable and do not bear foreign exchange risks associated with foreign borrowing. Surplus
cash and reserves are used to invest in expansion and technical improvement projects.

G.

Environmental and Social Issues

1.

Environment

75.
The Project is classified as environment category B as per ADB’s system of categorizing
projects, requiring a summary of the initial environmental examination report to be attached to the
ADB’s  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board.  A  preliminary  examination
indicates  that  there  will  not  be  any  deleterious  impact  on  the environment  that  cannot  be
mitigated. An initial environmental examination of the 230 kV and 132 kV transmission lines and
substations covered by Part A of the Project was conducted by PGCB. Other project components
have negligible impact on the environment.

76.
The summary initial environmental examination is attached as Appendix 9. Approximately
8 hectares of  land  will be acquired by  PGCB for the new  230 kV substation at  Aminbazar.  The
identified land is low lying and is flooded every year. Hence it supports no permanent population
or structures. There are also no trees on the identified site that need cutting. PGCB will need to
acquire right of way for the transmission lines that will be constructed. DESA will need to acquire
about 0.4 hectare of land for a new 132 kV substation at Kamrangichar. This does not have any
significant environmental impact.

2.

Social Analysis

77.
Project components were discussed  in detail by ADB  missions  with the  management as
well as the staff associations of BPDB and DESA, who in turn have briefed their members. ADB

 20

missions have also discussed the elements of the Project with potential beneficiaries, such as the
Federation of Bangladesh Chambers of Commerce and Industry, several industrialists, as well as
a few residential and commercial consumers of Dhaka. The beneficiaries are aware of the Project
and  support  the  power  sector  reforms  now  being  implemented.  The  staff  of  the  power  sector
utilities  support  the  Project,  but  have  expressed  reservations  regarding  the  restructuring  and
corporatization activities.

78.
The  Project  does  not  involve  significant  displacement  of  persons.  A  maximum  of  100
persons who are dispersed along the transmission line will be affected. A short resettlement plan
was prepared based on ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement  and is given in Appendix 10.
Minor rerouting of the transmission lines will be considered during project implementation, which
will further reduce the number of affected persons. Implementation of the plan for compensation
and resettlement will be closely monitored by ADB's review missions.

3.

Benefit Monitoring and Evaluation

79.
The benefit monitoring and evaluation of the Project will be done by PGCB, REB, DESCO,
and  DESA,  and  will  be  reviewed  by  ADB  missions  as  part  of  the  supervision  work.  This  will
include  verification  of  (i)  the  number  of  additional  connections  provided,  (ii)  the  consumer
categories of the new  connections, and  (iii) the  service  improvements for existing consumers  in
the  Dhaka  area.  Institutional  parameters  such  as  accounts  receivable,  accounts  payable,  and
system loss will also be evaluated.

V.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

Financial and Economic Analyses

1. 

Project Basis

80.
As part of its private power generation policy adopted in October 1996, the Government
has  invited  private  sector  investment  to  increase  the  generation  capacity  in  Bangladesh.
Proposals  were  solicited  for  about  1,400  MW  of  generating  capacity  on  a  BOO  basis.  It  is
expected that these capacities will be available within the next three years.

81.
Almost all incremental generation expected to come from the IPPs, is in the Dhaka area.
Consequently, to allow evacuation of power from the new plants, complementary investments in
transmission and distribution facilities are required. The completion of the 230 kV double-circuit
ring around Dhaka and upgrading of DESA’s and DESCO’s distribution network to allow import
of the newly available generation capacity is necessary given that Dhaka is the main center of
economic  activity  in  Bangladesh.  Appendix  11  presents  the  consumer  connection  summary,
which provides the basis for the financial and economic analyses of the Project.

2.

Financial Analysis

The financial evaluation of the Project was undertaken in real terms using constant 1998
82.
prices. The project cost estimates and financial projections in nominal terms were converted to
real terms by adjusting for the projected effects of foreign and domestic  inflation  and  currency
fluctuations. Incremental costs and benefits were derived by evaluating the financial position of
the EAs under with- and without-project scenarios. The weighted average financial internal rate
of return (FIRR) for the Project, computed on an after-tax basis, is 9.4 percent. This compares
favorably  with  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  (WACC),  also  computed  on  an  after-tax

 basis,  of  3.9  percent.  The  Project  is  considered  both  financially  viable  and  sustainable.
Sensitivity  analysis  indicates  that  the  weighted  average  FIRR  is  robust  under  adverse
conditions. The FIRR analysis is summarized in Table 8,  the  weighted average  cost of  capital
analysis is  summarized in Table 9. Detailed financial evaluation is provided in Appendix 12.

3.

Economic Rationale of the Project

Historically, the power sector has been operated  within a  relatively  monopolized  market,
83.
which  has  led  to  high  inefficiencies  and  uneconomic  resource  allocations.  To  address  the
necessary  sector  and  corporate  restructuring  and  governance  aspects,  the  Project  lends
investment  support  to  a  series  of  policy-based  initiatives  that  have  (i)  broken  monopolies,
(ii) introduced market-based mechanisms for competition and tariff setting, and (iii) redefined the
roles of the public and private sectors. The Project thereby facilitates movement towards a more
competitive market structure and financial accountability.

The creation of the new sector entities should instill discipline and financial viability into the
84.
sector. Presently, because of failure to manage the utilities properly, system losses and accounts
receivable  are  excessive  and  drain  the  sector  of  about  $80  million  per  year.  In  FY1995,
Government  loans  to  BPDB  of  $345 million  were  converted  to  equity.  This  meant  that  the
Government  had  foregone  the  domestic  mobilization  of  funds  inherent  in  the  onlending  of
development loans and grants to the  sector.  The Government’s equity in  DESA, of $260  million
has been made almost worthless because of operational losses incurred since DESA's creation in
FY1992.  Efforts  to  remove  the  drain  on  the  national  exchequer  and  improve  public  financial
management are essential to aid in macroeconomic management, which is one of the objectives
of the ADB’s policy on good governance. 21

                                               
21 Board Document No. R151-95:Governance: Sound Development Management.

 4.

Project Costs in Economic Prices

22

85.
The economic analysis uses border price levels with a world price numeraire and 1998
prices. To convert the financial capital cost into economic cost, taxes and duties were deducted.
No  price  contingencies  are  included  in  the  base  capital  cost.  However,  the  economic  capital
costs include 10 percent physical contingencies. The costs are separated into foreign exchange,
indirect  foreign  exchange,  and  local  currency  cost.  Local  costs  are  further  separated,  and
specific conversion factors  are  used  for  skilled  and  unskilled  labor.  The  remaining  local  costs
were  converted  to  border  price  levels  by  applying  a  standard  conversion  factor.  Annual
operation  and  maintenance  costs  were  calculated  in  economic  prices  as  a  percentage  of  the
total capital investment cost. It is assumed that after five years of full operation this percentage
will increase as more comprehensive maintenance works will be needed. The cost of energy at
the generation level is valued at the weighted average of IPP send-out cost of $.036/kWh. This
reflects the fact that all incremental generation capacity in the greater Dhaka area is expected to
be supplied by the IPPs. Transmission and distribution losses are included in the total amount of
energy to be imported into the transmission and distribution system.

5.

Project Benefits in Economic Prices

86.
Economic benefits of electricity  consumption  were calculated for each  major  consumer
category. For nonincremental consumption these are based on the alternative  economic  costs
of other energy sources such as diesel generators and kerosene lamps, which will be replaced
by  electricity.  The  elimination  of  load-shedding  is  used  as  a  proxy  to  estimate  the  amount  of
nonincremental consumption.

Once all load-shedding is eliminated, all additional electricity consumption is considered
87.
incremental. For example, it is expected that once reliable electricity supply is created there will
be  increased  purchase  for  more  sensitive  electrical  appliances  like  refrigerators  by  domestic
consumers  or  production  equipment  by  industries.  Incremental,  or  induced,  consumption  was
valued at the estimated average willingness to pay for electricity based on a weighted average
of  the  alternative  costs  of  providing  similar  energy-related  services  and  the  current  electricity
tariff for each consumer category. The evaluation is described in more detail in Appendix 13.

The  base  case  economic  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  for  the  Project  is  estimated  at
88.
22.7 percent.  The EIRR was calculated over a 20-year period, corresponding to the estimated
useful  life  of  the Project.  No  residual  value  was   considered.  Sensitivity  analysis for the  EIRR
demonstrates  that  the  Project  remains  viable  even  with  adverse  movements  in  some
parameters  such  as  increase  in  capital  cost,  increase  in  LRMC  at  the  generation  level,  or
construction delays. Results of a switching value analysis are also provided in Appendix 13.

6.

Macroeconomic Effects

89.
As  a  direct  consequence  of  the  sector  inefficiencies,  the  country  is  experiencing
substantial  power  supply  constraints  that  have  led  to  almost  daily  load-shedding.  Uninterrupted
power  supply  was  available  on  only  30  days  of  FY1999.  Scheduled  load-shedding  exists  in
parallel with the more frequent unscheduled load-shedding causing great disruption to economic
activity.22  Direct  short-run  costs  consist  of  spoilage  and  damage  due  to  unscheduled  loan-
shedding.  They  include  shutdown  and  restart  costs  of  equipment  and  reflect  the  opportunity
costs  of  under-utilization  of  production  factors  due  to  rescheduling  of  activities  as  a  result  of
controlled load-shedding. Indirect short-run costs reflect the multiplier effects resulting from the
typical interdependence between one firm’s input and another output. Long-run costs reflect the
                                               
22 This is based on Sanghvi, Arun P., 1991 Power Shortages in Developing Countries.

 23

consumers'  adaptation  strategies  as  a  result  of  their  expectations  that  power  shortages  will
persist.  In  the domestic  sector  this  can  result  in  the  purchase  of  voltage  regulators  to  protect
equipment and in investment in battery sets with inverters to run small appliances like fans and
televisions. In the industry sector, the unreliability of the grid supply has led to heavy investment
in captive generation.

A  World  Bank  study23  found  that  in  FY1998  alone,  generators  with  a  total  capacity  of
90.
50 MW were imported into Bangladesh at a total cost of $24 million. Since these machines run
mainly  on oil  or diesel,  the fuel  will  also  need  to be  imported,  and total  costs to  the  economy
could  be  as  high  as  $200  million.  These  expenditures  on  captive  power  generation  have
therefore  heavy  opportunity  costs  in  terms  of,  for  example,  reduced  investment  for  capacity
expansion  in  other  sectors,  and  represent  a  misallocation  of  funds.  In  addition  to  slowing
industrial output, power shortages  also result in increased imports and a decrease of exports,
with  potentially  adverse  impacts on  national  income, employment, foreign  exchange  reserves,
and foreign direct investments.

7.

Tariff Analysis

91.
The Electricity  Act  of  1910, as amended by  the  1972  Presidential  Decree  59,  requires
the electricity sector to earn a reasonable return after meeting its operating costs, debt service,
and  depreciation.  The  Government  is  responsible  for  making  tariff  adjustments,  except  in  the
case of the PBSs which, being privately owned, are able to set their own tariffs.

Until  September  1996, 

the  weighted  average  national 

92.
tariff  was  Tk2.34/kWh
($0.49/kWh),  or about 50  percent  of  the  LRMC  at  the  distribution  level  as  computed  in  1996.
The  Government  raised  electricity  tariffs  by  9.72  percent  effective  1  October  1996,  and  an
additional  5.21  percent  effective  1  December  1996,  for  a  total  increase  of  14.93  percent.
Effective 1 January 1997, tariffs are now reviewed every six months and automatically adjusted
as required, to take into account variations in key input costs, namely, fuel costs and exchange
rates,  the  last being  in  September 1999.  Future tariff  revisions  will  be  set  by  the  independent
regulatory commission that will be established as part of the reforms.

93.
  By  the  end  of  FY1998,  the  weighted  national  tariff  was  Tk2.76/kWh  ($.0575/kWh),
about 59 percent of the LRMC at the distribution level. However, with the commissioning of IPPs
with  lower  tariffs  over  the  next  few  years,  the  LRMC  will  be  reduced  substantially.  As  a
consequence, the average national retail tariff at its 1999 level will be about 71  percent of  the
recalculated LRMC at the distribution level. It is expected that the impact of the sector reforms,
which include specific targets for loss reductions, will contribute to an improving ratio of tariff to
LRMC.  With  poor  operating  efficiencies,  the  sector  penalizes  consumers  who  pay  for  their
electricity  rather  than  those  who  do  not.  Therefore,  raising  tariffs,  without  concomittant
improvements in efficiency is inequitable. In the future, the  regulatory  commission  will  have to
balance tariff revisions with the mandated efficiency improvements on the side of the utilities so
as not to punish customers who are paying their bills. In preparing financial projections for the
EAs,  it  is  assumed  that  average  bulk  tariffs  (including  transmission  charges)  will  remain
constant in nominal terms for the next six years, and from that time forward, will increase in line
with  domestic  inflation.  Average  retail  tariffs  are  projected  to  remain  constant  in  real  terms,
increasing only to reflect the effect of domestic inflation.

 B.

Social Dimensions

24

94.
The Project is designed to promote economic growth by increasing the access to electricity
supply in the Dhaka area, including the rural areas supplied by the PBSs from DESA. The Project is
expected  to  provide  a  reliable  power  supply,  thereby  improving  chances  of  industrialization  and
providing  employment  opportunities.  Reliable  electric  supply  will  also  enhance  education,  health,
and security facilities.

95.
Although the Project is essentially gender neutral, there are benefits that will be derived by
women  as  a  result  of  electricity  supply,  such  as  education,  security,  and  more  comfortable  living.
With  the  advantage  of  better  lighting,  women  can  spend  more  time  on  education  or  other  home-
based  vocations.  Community  televisions  in  the  villages  can  improve  general  knowledge  of  health,
hygiene, and prevention of diseases. Street lighting will provide better security to women after dark.
Further, women will derive distinctive benefits through their mandatory representation on the board
of directors of the PBSs. Each PBS reserves 5 of its 15 director seats for female advisers, who serve
as  channels  for  expression  of  women  development's  needs  in  the  given  area.  As  the  PBSs  are
responsible  for  planning  local  distribution  system  expansions,  the  Project  provides  women  with  a
chance to actively participate in the development process.

The  Project  furthers 

96.
the  development  of  the  PBSs,  which  are  special  purpose
nongovernment organizations. REB, as one of the project EAs, relies on the PBSs to operate and
maintain  the  distribution  network  after  physical  construction  is  completed  by  it,  thereby  shifting
responsibility for output sustainability to the PBSs. The PBSs operate on a nonprofit basis and do
not allow their annually elected unpaid directors to hold any political or government appointment,
mandate,  or  employment.  The  PBSs  have  multidimensional  development  roles  including
community  mobilization,  capacity  building,  and  direct  management  and  monitoring  of  project
outputs.

97.
The domestic tariff structure  incorporates a  lifeline tariff of Tk 2.00/kWh ($0.04) for the first
300 kWh per month.  This energy amount  is  more than  sufficient  to  cover  electricity  consumed  for
light, one or two fans, and small household appliances, which is considered the need for electricity
consumption  of  a  lower  middle  class  household.  While  increasing  tariffs  in  the  past,  it  has  been
ensured that this lifeline tariff is affordable by the lower income groups. About 100 kWh is expected
to meet basic needs of the urban and rural poor for lights and fans.

98.
Although there are no layoffs envisaged as part of this Project, the overall  reforms process
will, in the future, lead to surpluses of  certain categories of BPDB and DESA staff. Such staff can be
retrained  in  other  skills  for  redeployment  in  REB,  DESCO,  and  BPDB's  successor  organizations.
Staff who are  not  employable  in  the  sector  will  be  given  separation  compensation  packages.  The
power  sector agencies,  in  association  with  ADB  and  other  aid  agencies,  will  conduct  studies  next
year and evolve an appropriate scheme to mitigate the social impact of the reforms.

C.

Impact on Poverty

99.
As  per  ADB's  classification,  the  Project  does  not  directly  address  poverty  reduction
because  the  primary  beneficiaries  are  largely  the  industrial,  commercial,  and  domestic
consumers,  both  rural  and  urban,  in  the  Dhaka  area.  This  mix  of  consumers  is  important  to
safeguard the financial and  economic  viability of  the  Project.  However, the  Project  yields  very
attractive  economic  returns,  and  with  increasing  employment  opportunities  as  a  result  of
electrification,  there  will  be  trickle-down  benefits  for  the  poor.  Power  outages  affect  small
businesses  more  than  larger  ones  —  the  small  shopkeeper  and  the  artisan,  as  well  as  the
residential  consumers  who  cannot  afford  backup  generators.  Although  no
poorer 

 25

comprehensive  survey  was  carried  out,  estimates  from  various  manufacturers’  associations  in
Bangladesh indicate that industrial production could be about 10 percent higher if reliable power
is available in sufficient quantity. Power constraints have a direct impact on low-income workers
as  can  be  illustrated  by  the  example  of  the  ready-made  garment  manufacturing  (RMG)
industries.  RMG  manufacturing  plays  a  dominant  role  in  the  country’s  export  sector  and
contributes significantly to the national economy, but depends heavily on recurrent orders from
foreign  clients.  Once  a  producer  is  not  able  to  deliver  on  time  due  to  exogenous  factors  like
energy shortage it will be more difficult to secure new orders from international clients who were
defaulted.  Since  RMG  manufacturers  employ  about  1.5  million  workers,  including  about
1.25 million women, who constitute a significant fraction of the low-income population in Dhaka,
these will be the first to suffer from suspension of production and decline in foreign orders as the
workers are paid on a daily  basis  and  have  no  social  safety net.  Moreover,  the  income  of  the
garment  industry  workers  represents  a  major  share  of  business  for  the  owners  of  small-scale
retail outlets, who depend on the purchasing power of the RMG employees.  Thus  the Project,
by improving reliability of power supply has a direct impact on the poor, especially women.

100.
The  multiplier  effect  of  electricity  on  the  local  rural  economy  was  emphasized  by  the
findings  of  a  USAID-funded  comprehensive  field  study  carried  out  in  1996  to  investigate  the
economic  and  social  impact  of  the  rural  electrification  programs  implemented  through  the
PBSs.24 A general finding of the study was that the creation of PBSs has caused local markets
to expand and has given rise to a new class of entrepreneurs. Since the launch of the program,
6,000 direct jobs were created in the PBSs and REB. As the PBSs mature, and the industries
grow  more  established,  the  use  of  local  raw  material  also  increases  thereby  establishing  a
support economy  that  increases  local  employment and  cash  income.  This  has  resulted  in  the
creation of about 7,500 jobs at various industries and shops, which have opened in response to
the  demands  created  by  the  program.  The  establishment  of  industries  as  a  result  of
electrification,  their  growth,  and  the  creation  of  a  support  industry  for  industrial  inputs  has
another  beneficial  aspect  on  the  local  economy  —  the  gradual  development  of  local  demand
markets.

101. A  long-term research study on rural poverty,  25 published in 1995, covered 62  villages
representing 57 of 64 districts in Bangladesh. One of the articles compiled in the book analyzes
the  determinants  of  poverty  and  their  relative  significance.  One  of  the  six  major  factors
identified,  physical  infrastructure,  was  defined  to  comprise  rural  electrification,  irrigation,  and
transport facilities.

102.
The  methodology  employed  consisted  of  comparing  electrified  with  nonelectrified
villages. The incidence of poverty was estimated for electrified villages and was then compared
with  that  of  villages  without  access  to  electricity.  Poverty  was  substantially  reduced  on  with
spread  of  electrification.  Only  14  percent  of  the  residents  in  electrified  villages  are  hard  core
poor, defined as persons whose aggregate expenditure falls below the normative poverty line of
2,112 calories per day plus a 30 percent allowance for nonfood basis needs, as compared with
31 percent for unelectrified villages. The matched figure for moderate poverty is 27 percent and
31 percent respectively. It was thus concluded by the researchers that the extreme poor benefit
more from rural electrification than the moderate poor.

103.
Further, it was speculated that the benefit may have originated more from the generation
of employment opportunities in the rural nonfarm sector than from increasing the profitability per

                                               
24 Socioeconomic Impact Estimation of the Rural Electrification Program in Bangladesh,  NRECA  International  Ltd.,

USA for USAID.

25  Edited  by  Rahman,  H.Z.  and  Hossain,  M.  eds.  1995 Rethinking Rural Poverty – Bangladesh as a Case Study’

published by H.Z. Rahman in 1995, The University Press Limited, Chapter 15.5

 26

unit of land. This was supported by the finding that the incidence  of poverty for  households  in
the  land-size  category  of  2.5-4.3  acres  is  almost  the  same  for  electrified  and  nonelectrified
villages. For the functionally landless and the small farm households, poverty was found to be
substantially lower for villages with access to electricity.

 104. ADB recently initiated a study by staff consultants to undertake a similar kind of analysis
for the greater Dhaka area with a special focus on the urban poor. The study will quantify and
assess  the  socioeconomic  benefits  of  electrification  and  improved  electricity  supply.  In
particular,  the  study  will  analyze  the  actual  expenditures  on  energy  in  electrified  and
nonelectrified  households  for  comparable  energy  outputs,  and  the  impact  of  electrification  on
productive activities and on service delivery of public service institutions like clinics and schools.
The study will also explore whether a link between the  provision  of  reliable electricity  services
and expansion, turnover, and employment of micro and small business can be established. Until
now  all  research  has  focused  on  the  rural  population;  none  has  assessed  how  the  urban
population  is  coping  with  the  present  inadequate  energy  supply,  what  share  of  their
expenditures  is  allocated  for  energy  consumption,  which  of  their  activities  (industrial,
commercial,  household)  could  be  facilitated  by  switching  over  to  electricity  if  it  is  adequately
supplied, and up to what extent the urban poor would be willing and able to pay for enhanced
electricity services. Appendix 14 provides the outline terms of reference for the study.

D.

Project Risks

105.
The  success  of  the  Project  is  dependent  on  (i)  implementation  of  the  Meghnaghat
(Phase-1)  and  Haripur  projects,  at  least  by  FY2002;  and  (ii)  maintenance  of  tariffs  to  ensure
financial viability of PGCB, DESA and DESCO. The project FIRR and EIRR were tested for these
sensitivities  and  found  to  be  robust.  Additionally,  to  mitigate  the  first  risk,  the  Project  was
processed  only  after  the  contracts  for  the  Haripur  and  Meghnaghat  projects  were  signed.  To
minimize the second risk, (i) covenants were proposed to ensure the financial viability of PGCB,
DESA, and DESCO for the short term; and (ii) the legal framework for the sector is being changed
and  an  independent  regulatory  authority  established.  The  ADB  has  accorded  TA  to  the  new
regulatory authority to support its operationalization 26.

A.

Specific Assurances

VI.

ASSURANCES

The  Government,  DESA,  DESCO,  PGCB,  and  REB  have  given  the  following
106.
assurances, in addition to the standard assurances, which have been incorporated in the legal
documents:

(i)

Until the establishment of an energy regulatory body, the Government will ensure
that PGCB’s transmission tariffs are reviewed every six months and are adjusted
to  reflect  the  impacts  of  inflation  and  foreign  currency  fluctuations.  The
transmission  tariffs  will  be  sufficient  to  ensure  full  cost  recovery  for  operation,
maintenance  and  financial  charges,  and  an  adequate  rate  of  return  on
investment. 

(ii)

By  30  June  2000,  (a)  DESA  will  transfer  its  assets  in  the  Gulshan  distribution
circle to DESCO; and (b) the Government will cause BPDB to transfer to PGCB

                                               
26 TA No. 3129-BAN: Support for an Energy Regulatory Authority, for $900,000, approved on 16 December 1998.

 27

the Tongi and Hasnabad 230 kV substations and the Haripur-Hasnabad 230 kV
transmission line, all under arrangements satisfactory to ADB.

The Government will ensure that all local currency funds required for the Project
are (i) committed in advance of its Annual Development Program on the basis of
anticipated expenditure for the relevant year, and (ii) transferred to the concerned
Project EAs at least three months prior to the anticipated need or disbursement.

The Government will cause DESA, DESCO, PGCB, and REB to carry out benefit
monitoring and evaluation activities under the Project for their respective Parts of
the Project. These activities will be reviewed periodically by ADB and will include
verification of the number of new connections, the consumer categories of such
connections,  and  the  improvement  of  service  to  consumers  in  Dhaka  and  its
environs.

PGCB will implement land acquisition and compensation under the Project on a
timely  basis  in  accordance  with  the  resettlement  plan  agreed  upon  by  the
Borrower,  PGCB and  ADB.  The Government,  PGCB and  ADB  will  carry out  an
assessment  of  the  resettlement  plan  during  the  second  year  of  Project
implementation. If the number of persons to be resettled is assessed to be more
than  100,  PGCB  will  prepare  and  implement  a  revised  resettlement  plan
satisfactory to ADB.

By FY2003, DESCO will maintain the following operational standards: (i) systems
losses of not more than 18 percent computed on a monthly basis; (ii) a collection
to  import  ratio  of  not  less  than  75  percent,  and  as  from  FY2005,  not  less  than
80 percent;  (iii)  accounts  receivable  to  represent  not  more  than  two months  of
sales;  and  (iv)  payables  for  electricity  import  to  represent  not  more  than  one
month’s average import.

By FY2003, DESA will maintain the following operational standards:  (i)  systems
losses of not more than 18 percent computed on a monthly basis; (ii) a collection
to import ratio of not less than 80 percent; (iii) accounts  receivable  to  represent
not  more  than  two  months  of  sales;  and  (iv)  payables  for  electricity  import  to
represent not more than six months of electricity purchases.

By  FY2003,  REB  will  cause  the  PBSs  to  maintain  the  following  operational
standards:  (i)  systems  losses  of  not  more  than  18  percent  computed  on  a
monthly  basis;  (ii)  a  collection  to  import  ratio  of  not  less  than  80  percent;
(iii) accounts  receivable  to  represent  not  more  than  three  months  of  sales;  and
(iv)  payables  for  electricity  import  to  represent  not  more  than  two  months  of
electricity purchases.

By FY 2003, PGCB will maintain the following operational standards: (i) a loss of
load  probability of  less  than  1  percent; and  (ii)  transmission  losses at  less  than
4 percent.

The  Government  will  make  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  to  invest  in
DESCO as cash equity as follows: in FY2000, Tk300 million; and in FY2001 and
FY2002, Tk400 million for each fiscal year.

The  Government  will  make  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  to  invest  in
PGCB as  cash  equity  as  follows:  in  FY2001,  Tk100  million;  and  in  FY2002,
Tk 300 million.
