As  from  FY2003,  DESCO  will  maintain  (i)  a  debt  service  coverage  ratio  of  not
less than 1.2; (ii) a current ratio of not less than 1.1; and (iii) a debt to equity ratio
of not more than 70 to 30.

DESCO will ensure that dividends are not declared unless DESCO maintains, for
a  period  of  at  least 12  consecutive  months,  (i)  a debt service  coverage  ratio  of
not less than 1.3; (ii) a current ratio of not less than 1.2; and (iii) a cash balance
representing not less than 6 months of future debt service obligations.

As  from  FY2003,  REB  will  cause  the  PBSs  to  maintain  (i)  a  debt  service
coverage ratio of not less than 1.2; and (ii) a current ratio of not less than 1.1.

As from FY2003, PGCB will maintain: (i) a debt service coverage ratio of not less
than 1.2; (ii) a current ratio of not less than 1.1; and (iii) a debt to equity ratio of
not more than 70 to 30.

(xvi)  PGCB will ensure that dividends are not declared unless PGCB maintains, for a
period of at least 12 consecutive months, (i) a debt service coverage ratio of not
less  than  1.3;  (ii)  a current  ratio  of  not  less  than  1.2; and  (iii)  a  cash  balance
representing not less than 6 months of future debt service obligations.

Conditions of Award of Contract

107. Each  Project  EA  will  not  award  any  contract  under  the  Project  until  all  arrangements
relating to physical and legal transfer of assets pertaining to such contract have been completed
in a manner satisfactory to ADB.

of the ADB and recommend that the Board approve:

interest charge at the  rate of 1  percent per annum  during the  grace  period and
1.5 percent  per  annum  thereafter,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  Loan  and  Project
Agreements presented to the Board; and

the  loan  of  $82,000,000  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  to  the  People’s

 Appendix 7

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR THE TECHNICAL AND MANAGEMENT
DEVELOPMENT INSTITUTE

The  Rural  Electrification  Board  (REB)  proposes  to  establish  a  modern  technical  and
1. 
management  development  institute  to provide  training  and  development  to  the  managers  and
staff of the Palli Bidyut Samities (PBSs). This program will also incorporate upgraded versions
of the technical training currently provided by REB.

2. 

The consultant will:

(i) 

review  the  current  training,  both  technical  and  managerial,  being  provided  by
REB to staff of the PBSs;

(ii) 

review REB's facilities for training and management development;

(iii) 

(iv) 

(v) 

(vi) 

(vii) 

develop  an  appropriate  curriculum  for  the  institute,  taking  into  account  the
technical and managerial long-term needs of the PBSs;

design the delivery of the program and identify hardware as  well  as faculty and
training resources for the suggested curriculum;

develop the detailed designs for the institute buildings and facilities, prepare bid
documents  for  its  construction,  assist  with  the  bid  process,  and  supervise
construction;

provide  assistance  in  locating  appropriate  faculty  for  delivering  the  training
programs; and

suggest methods to progressively introduce more local training faculty, including
training for trainers.

It  is  expected  that  about  30  person-months  of  international  consulting  will  be  needed
3. 
from  a  firm  specializing  in  conceptualization,  design,  architecture,  and  engineering  of  training
and  management  development  institutes.  The  consultants  will  be  supported  by  about
50 person-months  of  domestic  consulting  with  expertise  in  engineering,  architecture,  and
training methods.

4.
In  addition  to  consulting  services,  the  Project  will  also  include  provision  of  up  to
20 person-months  of  international  and  20  person-months  of  domestic  faculty  to  develop  and
deliver key training programs, as well as funds to purchase training aids and equipment.

It  is  expected that  the  services  will  commence  in  July 2000 and be completed  in  June

5.
2003.

 Appendix 8, page 1

FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE AND PROJECTIONS

A. 

General

The  Project  will  be  executed  by  four  separate  executing  agencies:  (i)  Part  A  will  be
1.
executed  by  Power  Grid  Company  of  Bangladesh  (PGCB);  (ii)  Part  B(i)  by  the  Rural
Electrification Board (REB); (iii) Part B(ii) by the Dhaka Electric Supply Company (DESCO); and
(iv)  Part  B(iii)  by  the  Dhaka  Electric  Supply  Authority  (DESA).  Upon  completion  of  Part  B(i),
assets, operation and debt repayment obligations will pass from REB to the seven Palli Bidyut
Samitys  (PBSs)  participating  in  the  Project  (Dhaka-1,  Dhaka-2,  Narshingdi-1,  Narshingdi-2,
Manikgonj,  Mymensing-1,  and  Munshigonj).  The  PBSs  are  rural  electricity  cooperatives.  Both
PGCB  and  DESCO  are  limited  liability  companies  registered  under  the  Companies  Act  1994;
PGCB was incorporated on 21 November 1996 and DESCO on 3 November 1996. DESA is a
statutory  authority  of  the  Government  created  by  the  DESA  Ordinance  of  1990  (Presidential
Ordinance No. 6 of 1990).

Financial  projections  were  completed  on  an  executing  agency  basis.  As  asset
2.
ownership, debt service obligations, and operating and maintenance responsibilities for Part B(i)
will eventually lie with the PBSs, a consolidated model was produced based on the actual and
projected performance of the seven PBSs.

B. 

Past Financial Performance

3.
Although  established  in  1996,  PGCB  has  just  commenced  commercial  operations.
Balance sheets and statements of  preliminary expenses have been  maintained  in accordance
with acceptable accounting standards.

4.
Of  the  seven  PBSs  participating  in  the  Project,  five  have  existing  operations.  Two,
Dhaka-2  and  Munshigonj,  are  newly  established  PBSs.  At  Project  appraisal,  the  financial
positions of the operational  PBSs  varied.  Dhaka-1  and  Narshingdi-1  are  performing  well,  with
healthy balance sheets and  sound  profitability.  The  remaining  three are  in  the  initial  stages  of
operation, balance sheets are sound, and they are gradually improving their overall profitability,
however they continue to rely heavily on Government subsidies.

5.
Although  incorporated  in  1996,  DESCO  began  commercial  operations  in  September
1998  when  approximately  58  percent  of  DESA’s  Mirpur  distribution  circle  was  formally
transferred from DESA. At project appraisal, DESCO had completed nine months of operations.
Initial  operating  performance  was  lower  than  originally  expected.  The  actual  number  of
consumers absorbed from DESA was considerably higher  than  DESA  records  indicated.  This,
coupled  with  some  initial  start-up  problems  resulted  in  financial  losses  during  these  first  few
months  of  operation.  While  this  is  to  be  expected  from  a  start-up  company,  DESCO
management has been requested to implement measures to improve the overall situation.

DESA  commenced  operations  in  1991,  upon  separation  from  the  Bangladesh  Power
6.
Development  Board  (BPDB).  Legal  title  to  distribution  assets  in  the  Dhaka  Metropolitan  Area
was transferred to DESA with the corresponding long-term domestic and foreign debt. After six
years of commercial operations, with dismal operational and financial performance, DESA has a
negative net worth as of 30 June 1998 of Tk.2,374 million.

 Appendix 8, page 2

C

Financial Projections

1. 

General

The effect of the proposed Project on  the financial  position of PBCB,  the  seven  PBSs,
7.
DESCO,  and  DESA  are  reflected  in  the  financial  projections  for  PGCB  (presented  in  Tables
A8.1  -  A8.3),  the  PBSs  (Tables  A8.4-A8.6),  DESCO  (Tables  A8.7-A8.9)  and  DESA  (Tables
A8.10-A8.12).  These  have  been  prepared  on  a  nominal  basis  based  on  major  assumptions
outlined in the following paragraphs.

8.
Domestic inflation rates are assumed to be 7 percent for 1999, 5 percent for 2000, and
4.5  percent  thereafter,  while  international  inflation  rates  are  assumed  to  be  2.4  percent
throughout the projection period.

9.
Although it is expected that the entire asset base of DESA will be absorbed by DESCO
in the near future, the exact timing and details of the transfer were unclear at the time of project
appraisal. As such, DESA financial performance is projected to 2020 in line with the projections
prepared and presented for PGCB, the PBSs, and DESCO.

2. 

Revenues and Cost of Sales

a. 

Transmission Revenues/Electricity Sales

10.
PGCB’s  revenues  are  derived  from  the  transmission  of  electricity.  A  partial  transfer  of
transmission assets from BPDB  was  effected  in  October  1999.  It  has  been  assumed  that  the
transfer of assets associated with the Project will be completed by 1 July 2000 with the balance
of BPDB transmission assets being transferred to PGCB by 1 July 2003.  For the purpose of the
financial projections, it has been assumed that the transmission tariff will computed following a
full cost recovery methodology. An Operating and Maintenance provision has been assumed at
2.0 percent of average fixed asset balance increased in line with domestic inflation. In addition
depreciation, foreign exchange  losses  and  taxes have been covered  by  the  tariff.  It  has  been
assumed  that  a  gross  margin  on  average  historical  fixed  assets  of  10  percent  constitutes  a
reasonable return.

11.
For  the  purpose  of  the  financial  projections,  it  is  assumed  that  the  PBSs  will  assume
ownership of assets and the customer base associated with the Project by the end of December
1999, and that DESCO will assume ownership of assets and the customer base of the Gulshan
Distribution  Circle  by  1  July  2000.  Sales  projections  are  based  on  consumer  connection
summaries provided by REB and DESA. It is assumed that growth in electricity sales will result
from  (i)  reduced  brownouts  and  availability  of  additional  power  from  the  Independent  Power
Producer  (IPP)  plants;  (ii)  new  consumption  as  a  result  of  project  investments;  and  (iii) new
consumption as a result of efficiency improvements.

b.

Electricity Importation

12.
The PBSs and DESCO purchase power from BPDB and DESA; DESA purchases power
directly from  BPDB.  The  amount  of  power  purchased  will  be  a  function  of  consumer  demand
and system losses. According to PBS records, system losses, both technical and nontechnical,
range  from  14  to  40  percent  of  bulk  power  purchases.  It  is  assumed  that  through  technical
improvements  and  efficiency  measures,  the  PBSs  will  be  able  to  reduce  the  losses  to
14 percent  over  seven  years  after  assuming  operations  of  a  distribution  area  from  DESA.
According  to  DESA  records,  historical  systems  losses,  both  technical  and  nontechnical,

 Appendix 8, page 3

amounted  to  27  percent  of  bulk  power  purchases  for  the  Dhaka  Metropolitan  Area  (after
segregating  the  rural  distribution  areas handed  over  to  the  PBSs).  It  is  assumed  that  through
technical improvements and efficiency measures, that DESCO and DESA will be able to reduce
systems losses to 18 percent over a five-year period.

c.

Bulk Power Purchase and Retail Tariffs

13.
The PBSs, and DESA purchase power at a bulk selling rate. DESCO purchases power
from DESA at the bulk rate plus a 2.5 percent wheeling charge. Since 1996, bulk power tariffs
have  been  reviewed  and  adjusted  every  six  months  with  average  increases  of  approximately
3 to 4 percent per annum. With the commissioning of the IPP plants, the overall efficiency in the
generation subsector is expected to improve dramatically, and the efficiency gains are expected
to  compensate  for  any  increase  in  general  price  levels.  As  such,  it  is  expected  that  the  bulk
power tariff will remain constant until 2003 and will increase in line with domestic inflation from
2004 onward.

The PBSs have the authority to set retail tariffs, with the exception of agricultural tariffs,
14.
which  are  established  by  the  Government.  Tariffs  are  reviewed  regularly;  the  PBSs  tend  to
charge about 50 percent higher than DESA or DESCO. Given the projected stability in the bulk
power tariff, it is assumed that the average retail tariff will level off and remain constant in real
terms, therefore, the assumed growth in the weighted average retail tariff is limited to effects of
domestic inflation.

15.
It is assumed that DESCO will sell electricity to consumers following DESA’s retail tariff
structure.  DESA’s  retail  tariffs  are  reviewed  every  six  months,  and  since  1995,  have  been
increasing  at  a  rate  of  approximately  8  percent  per  annum.  However,  given  the  projected
stability  of  the  bulk  power  tariff,  it  is  assumed  that  the  average  retail  tariff  will  level  off  and
remain constant in real terms, therefore the assumed growth in the weighted average retail tariff
is limited to the effects of domestic inflation.

3. 

Expenses

a. 

Operating Expenses

16.
It  is  assumed  that  PGCB’s  operating  expenses  will  include  repairs  and  maintenance,
materials  and  equipment,  salaries  and  wages,  contract  labor,  and  administrative  charges.
Financial  projections  are  based  on  a  budget  prepared  by  the  company  and  local  costs  are
projected to increase in line with domestic inflation. An average depreciation rate of 3.0 percent
per annum is charged, on a declining balance basis, against the historical value of fixed assets.
Preliminary expenses are amortized over a 10-year period commencing in 2001.

17.
It  is  assumed  that  the  PBSs  operating  expenses  include  distribution,  consumer
accounts,  consumer  services,  sales,  administrative  and  general  expenses,  and  depreciation.
Expenses are based on historical performance, taking into consideration the impact of domestic
inflation.  An  average  depreciation  rate  of  3.0  percent  per  annum  is  charged,  on  a  declining
balance basis, against the historical value of fixed assets.

It is assumed that DESCO’s operating expenses will include operation and maintenance,
18.
commercial  (billing  and  collections),  salaries  and  wages,  depreciation,  amortization,  and
administrative  charges.  The  level  of  operating  expenses  is    based  on  existing  contracts,  and
budgets prepared by DESCO taking into account the impact of domestic  inflation.  An  average
depreciation rate of 5 percent per annum is charged, on a declining balance basis, against the

 Appendix 8, page 4

historical  value  of  fixed  assets.  Preliminary  expenses  and  computer  software  development
expenditures are amortized over a five-year period commencing in 1999.

19.
It  is  assumed  that  DESA’s  operating  expenses  will  include  distribution,  commercial,
general, administrative, and depreciation expense. Expense assumptions are based on DESA’s
historical  financial  performance  adjusted  to  reflect  the  impact  of  assets  and  operations
transferred  to  DESCO  and  the  PBSs  under  ADB's    Ninth Power Project 1 and  the  proposed
Project.  An  average  depreciation  rate  of  3.2  percent  per  annum  is  charged,  on  a  declining
balance basis, against fixed assets.

b. 

Interest Expense

PGCB’s  current  debt  position  was  analyzed,  and  based  on  available  information,  an
20.
amortization  schedule  was  prepared  to  project  annual  interest  expenditures.  PBCB  has
assumed  debt  and  equity  associated  with  assets  transferred  from  BPDB.  In  addition,  future
capital expansion will be financed  through  a  combination  of  equity, domestic and  international
debt, and  supplier’s  credit.  Interest  expense  under Ninth Power Project  was  computed  on  the
basis of a Special Funds resources (SFR) service charge of 1 percent per annum together with
a domestic markup of 7 percent per annum. Interest expense for the Project loan is computed
on the basis of an ordinary capital resources (OCR) interest charge estimated at 7 percent per
annum with a local mark-up of 1 percent per annum.

21.
The PBSs carry debt associated with capital expansion activities. The entire capital cost
is  booked  as  debt  to  the  PBSs,  however,  the  interest  and  repayment  terms  are  heavily
subsidized. The existing debt situation at 30 June 1998 was analyzed and debt amortization and
interest expense used in the financial projections is based on that analysis. Interest expense for
the loan associated with the Project was computed on the basis of an SFR  interest charge of
1.5  percent  per  annum  with  a  local  markup  of  1.5  percent  per  annum.  The  PBSs  are  not
responsible  for  the  foreign  currency  risk,  as  such,  foreign-sourced  borrowings  are  booked  in
domestic currency.

22.
DESCO assumed debt and equity in association with the transfer of assets from DESA.
It is assumed that the interest rate on debt to DESA will be 8 percent per annum. The interest
expense  on  Ninth Power Project  was  computed  on  the  basis  of  an  SFR  service  charge  of
1 percent per annum together with a domestic markup of 7 percent per annum. Interest expense
for the project loan is computed on the basis of an OCR interest charge estimated 7 percent per
annum with a local markup of 1 percent per annum. The existing and proposed Bank lending is
the only foreign debt held by DESCO.

DESA  carries  a  heavy  debt  burden,  with  significant  domestic  and  foreign  currency
23.
denominated  debt.  The  existing  debt  situation  as  of  30  June  1998  was  analyzed,  and  debt
amortization  and  interest expense  is  based  upon  that  analysis.  Interest  expense  on  loan  was
computed on the basis of an SFR service charge of 1 percent together with a domestic markup
of 7 percent per annum. Interest expense for the project loan was computed on the basis of an
SFR interest charge of 1.5 percent per annum with a local markup of 6.5 percent per annum.

c. 

Tax Expense and Dividend Payment

24.
The PBSs, given their cooperative status, are exempt from payment of corporate income
tax.  For  PGCB,  DESCO,  and  DESA  income  tax  is  computed  at  40  percent  per  annum.  It  is

                                               
1 

Loan BAN 1505(SF):Ninth Power, for $134.4 million, approved on 18 December 1996.

 further assumed that PGCB and DESCO will be in a position to begin distributing dividends by
2006.  Dividends  are  assumed  after  taking  into  account  future  debt  service  obligations  and
working capital requirements.

Appendix 8, page 5

4.

Balance Sheet Assumptions

a. 

Accounts Receivable

Until such time as the entire balance of national transmission assets are transferred from
25.
BPDB  to  PGCB,  it  is  assumed  that  the  entire  wheeling  charge  will  be  paid  by  BPDB,  in  its
capacity as power generator. The number of total customers is expected to be relatively small.
As  such,  it  is  assumed  that  accounts  receivable  will  represent  one  month’s  sales  and  will
backed  by  a  line  of  credit  issued  by  the  customers.  As  such,  no  provision  is  assumed  for
doubtful accounts.

26.
Accounts  receivable  for  the  PBSs,  as  of  30  June  1998,  on  average  represent  almost
5 months’ total sales. It is assumed that as the PBSs gain operational experience, they will be
able to reduce this, on average to 3 months by 2002. It is assumed that a provision for doubtful
accounts will be maintained at 5 percent of the total accounts receivable balance.

Following  9  months  of  initial  operations,  DESCO’s  accounts  receivable  balance
27.
represented 6 months total sales. This was due in part to initial problems with the metering and
billing systems, which resulted in delayed production and presentation of invoices. As DESCO
improves  its  internal  systems  and  gains  operational  experience,  it  is  expected  that  accounts
receivable  will  represent  4  months,  sales  by  the  year  2000  and  then  will  be  maintained  at
2 months’ sales thereafter. It has further assumed that a provision for doubtful accounts will be
maintained at 10 percent of the total accounts receivable balance.

Accounts receivable for DESA, as of 30 June 1998, represented 12 month’s sales. It has
28.
been  assumed  that  80  percent  of  this  will  be  recovered  over  a  five-year  period,  with  the
remaining 20 percent written off over the  same period.  From  1999 onward,  it  is  assumed  that
accounts receivable from new sales will represent 2 months sales. It is assumed that a provision
for doubtful accounts will be maintained at 10 percent of the accounts receivable balance.

b.

Inventory

It  is  assumed  that  PGCB  and  DESCO  will  maintain  an  inventory  balance  of
29.
approximately  3  months  usage  of  materials  and  spare  parts,  and  that  DESA  will  maintain  an
inventory balance of approximately 6 months usage of materials and spare parts. PBS inventory
levels are projected based upon existing levels adjusted for the planned capital expansion.

c.

Accounts Payable

It has been assumed that PGCB’s accounts payable will include 1 month of repairs and
30.
maintenance,  contract  fees,  inventory  procurement,  and  administrative  charges.  It  is  also
assumed that the PBSs accounts payable will include 2 months of  electricity import, 5 months
other  operating  expenses,  and  six  months  annual  procurement  of  inventory  and  supplies.
DESCO’s accounts payable are  assumed  to  include one  month  of electricity  import,  operation
and maintenance, commercial, inventory procurement, and administrative expenditures.

31.
As  of  30  June  1998,  accounts  payable  from  DESA  to  BPDB  represented  almost
12 months  of  electricity  import.  It  is  assumed  that  this  will  be  reduced  to  6  months  by  2002.

 Appendix 8, page 6

Trade  accounts  payable  for  DESA  are  assumed  to  represent  two  months  of  operation  and
maintenance, commercial, inventory procurement, and administrative expenditures.

d. 

Capital Expenditures

32.
Capital  expenditures  are  based  on  the  ongoing  capital  expenditure  and  expansion
programs  for  PGCB,  the  PBSs,  DESCO,  and  DESA  to  2005.  Financing  for  the  planned
expenditures will be from domestic debt and equity, bilateral assistance, and supplier credit. For
the purposes of the financial projections, given the uncertainty for timing and amount of future
expenditures, it is assumed that no further investment in capital assets will be made after 2005.

e. 

Long-Term Debt

33.
As  indicated  in  para.  23,  PGCB’s  existing  debt  position  was  analyzed  and  based  on
available  information,  an  amortization  schedule  was  prepared  to  project  annual  interest
expenditures,  foreign  exchange  losses  (on  foreign  denominated  debt),  and  debt  service
obligations.  It  is assumed  that  the project  loan  will  have  a  four-year  grace  period  (to  coincide
with the construction timetable) and a 16-year repayment period.

34.
As indicated in para. 24, the existing debt position of the PBSs was analyzed, and based
on  available  information,  an  amortization  schedule  was  prepared  to  project  annual  interest
expenditures and debt service  obligations.  It  is assumed  that the project  loan  will  be provided
with a 5-year grace period and a 20-year repayment period (onlending terms between REB and
the PBSs).

35.
DESCO’s foreign-denominated,  long-term  debt  is  approximately  $24.3  million  provided
under loan  1505 and  approximately  $26.4  million for  the proposed project  loan.  It  is  assumed
that  the  loan  will  be  granted  with  a  4-year  grace  period  and  a  16-year  repayment  period.
DESCO’s domestic debt is limited to Tk405 million due to DESA as a result of the transfer of the
Mirpur and Gulshan distribution area assets. The transfer of assets, valued at DESA’s net book
value, has been assumed to be financed on a 60:40 debt to equity ratio. It is assumed that the
debt due to DESA will be provided with a 1-year grace period and a 15-year repayment period.

36.
As  indicated  in para. 26,  the  existing  debt  situation  of  DESA  as  of  30  June  1998  was
analyzed,  and  debt  amortization  and  interest  expense  are  based  upon  that  analysis.  It  is
assumed  that  the  project  loan  will  be  provided  with  a  4-year  grace  period  and  a  16-year
repayment period.

f. 

Share Capital

37.
It is assumed that PGCB's share capital will increase due to (i) equity financing of assets
transferred  from  BPDB;  (ii)  counterpart  financing  under  loan  1505;  (iii) counterpart  financing
under the Project; (iv) counterpart financing for ongoing expansion projects (i.e., not financed by
the ADB); and (v) additional equity contributions of Tk400 million for 2001-2002. It is assumed
that  64  percent  of  the  domestic  financing  obligations  of  the  Project  will  be  financed  through
equity to comply with the overall debt-equity requirement for the Project of 70:30.

The PBSs have a cooperative ownership structure. Rather than share capital, member's
38.
equity  is derived from  member’s  subscriptions.  The entire  project  cost  will  be  passed  on  from
REB to the PBSs as a loan, denominated in taka and with concessionary terms; therefore, no
increase in member equity is projected.

 Appendix 8, page 7

It is assumed that DESCO's share capital will increase due to (i) equity financing of asset
39.
transfers from  DESA;  (ii) counterpart  financing  requirements  under  loan  1505;  (iii)  counterpart
financing requirements under the Project; and (iv) additional equity contributions of Tk1,100 due
from  the  Government  during  the  2000-2003.  It  is  assumed  that  75  percent  of  the  domestic
financing obligations of the Project will be financed through equity to comply with the debt-equity
requirement of 70:30.

40.
It  is  assumed  DESA  capital  will  increase  as  a  result  of  the  counterpart  financing
requirements  under  the  Project.  It  is  assumed  that  57  percent  of  the  domestic  financing
obligations of the Project will be financed through  equity  to  comply  with an overall  debt-equity
requirement of 70:30.

 SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION

Appendix 9, page 1

A.

Introduction

An  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  was  carried  out  by  the  Power  Grid  Company  of
1.
Bangladesh  Ltd.  and  its  consultants  for  the  Dhaka  Power  System  Upgrade  Project.  The  IEE
was submitted to the Department of Environment (DOE) of the Ministry of Environment and Forest on
4 July  1999.  The  DOE  issued  site  clearance  on  16  September  1999.  The  ADB’s  environment
specialist visited the project site on 15 May 1999 to confirm the ADB’s categorization of the Project as
category B, a project with minor environmental impacts that could be easily mitigated using available
technologies. The project components are described in paras. 40-42 of the main text.

B.

Description of the Environment

2.
The  project  sites  for  Part  A  consist  of  the  existing  Tongi,  Kalyanpur,  and  Hasnabad
substations, additional 2,000 sqare meter (m2) beside the Kalyanpur substation, 20 acres of land for
the  new  Aminbazar  substation  and  the  60  km  right-of-way  for  the  transmission  facilities.  Tongi,
Kalyanpur,  and  Hasnabad  substations  are  located  in  the  mixed  land  uses,  primarily  industrial  and
residential, areas that have sprouted up with the availability of more reliable power sources compared
with other areas of Dhaka. No new transformers will be installed at the existing premises of Tongi and
Hasnabad substations. Two bays with associated equipment and gantries will be installed each within
the  existing  premises  of  these  substations.  At  Kalyanpur  substation,  a  new  transformer  and
associated equipment and gantry structure will be installed; this requires additional 2,000 m2 of land to
be  acquired  from  an  adjacent  vacant  industrial  land  owned  by  a  state  agency  of  Bangladesh
Agricultural Development Corporation. The area to be used for expansion of the substation facilities in
those areas was cleared and is being maintained for future expansion. The lands are fenced by a 3-m
high concrete wall, and all installations including the proposed expansion are built 3 m from the wall
for security purposes. Part B and Part C will not require acquisition of land except about 0.4 hectare of
land for a new 132 kilovolt (kV) substation at Kamrangichar in Dhaka.

3.
The  20  acres  of  land  to  be  acquired  for  the  Aminbazar  substation  is  between  two  existing
transmission lines and approximately 200 m  away  from  the highway.  It  is  part  of  an artificial  lagoon
that has developed from the manufacture of bricks and was to be a source of fill materials for earlier
real estate development in Dhaka. Brick production is still ongoing at  the  other  side  of  the highway.
The area  has  marginal  uses  although  some  merchants  have  started  to  fill  the  area  adjacent  to  the
highway to build stores. Aminbazar is on the outer fringe of Dhaka.

4.
The  air  and  water  quality  around  Tongi,  Aminbazar,  Kalyanpur,  and  Hasnabad  are  polluted
from industrial and domestic waste discharges. Most of the industries in Tongi and Kalyanpur are in
textile and garment manufacturing, which require large quantities of hot water. The factories operate
boilers using fuel oil  and  sometimes using  wastes  and scrap  materials.  The  boilers  have  little  or no
pollution  control  facilities.  The  storm  drains  are  also  the  main  receivers  of  wastewater  discharges.
Dyes  and  highly  colored  wastewater  are  discharged  in  the  storm  drains.  Hasnabad  is  less
industrialized.  The  northern  portion  of  Hasnabad  substation  is  bounded  by  the  Buriganga  River.
Ferryboats  serving  Dhaka  and  other  parts  of  the  country  use  the  riverbanks  in  the  vicinity  of  the
substation. The eastern and southern sections are cultivated with rice. The western section is a mixed
industrial and residential area.

From  Tongi  substation,  the  transmission  line  will  pass  2  km  of  mixed  land  use  area
5.
surrounding  the  substation.  The  air  and  water  quality  in  this  section  is  heavily  polluted.  Then  the
transmission  line  right-of-way  will  move  in  parallel  to  the  outer  section  of  the  flood  control  bund
protecting Dhaka city and 50 m from an existing transmission  line through  Aminbazar to  Hasnabad.
The area outside of the bund is subject to 4 m flood during the peak of the monsoon season. The air

 Appendix 9, page 2

and  water  quality  in  this  section  is  relatively  unpolluted.  The  main  source  of  air  pollution  is  from
vehicular traffic and industries transported from the other side of the bund. As the water level on this
side  of  the  bund  is  often  higher  than  in  the  heavily  populated  section  of  Dhaka,  contamination  is
minimal.  The  transmission  line  will  pass  through  some  built  up  areas  near  the  Savar  Highway  and
close to the proposed Aminbazar substation and in the vicinity of the Hasnabad substation.

6.
The  land  in  Tongi,  Kalyanpur,  Aminbazar,  and  Hasnabad  substations  has  been  utilized  for
industrial  and  residential  purposes  for  a  long  time.  For  safety  purposes,  the  open  space  within  the
substation  was  cleared  of  grasses  and  other  vegetation,  which  could  accidentally  flare  up.  The
perimeter  clearance  was  cemented  to  facilitate  movement  of  maintenance  equipment  and  crew.
Native  flora  and  fauna  have  long  been  dislocated  in  adjacent  industrial  and  residential  areas.  The
existing flora and fauna are typical of urban ecology consisting mostly of household pets, insects and
domesticated animals.

7.
The ecology in the proposed Aminbazar  substation  is  aquatic.  It  is expected  that  only  plants
occurring in seasonally flooded condition will be met in the project area. No forested vegetation was
observed in the project area. The aquatic flora and fauna have little or no commercial value nor are
they endangered or protected. The area is an artificial lagoon.

8.
The flora and fauna in the transmission line right-of-way varies from those of urban ecology in
built up areas such as those around the substations.  Most of the area transversed by the right-of-way
is  flooded  for  most  of  the  year.   When  the  land  is  not  flooded  it  is  cultivated  with  rice  and  aquatic
vegetables. Within  the project area,  there  is  no natural  forest  vegetation.  The  terrestrial  flora  of  the
project consists mainly homestead plants. In addition, a large number of fruit and  horticultural  crops
are  grown  in  the  homestead.  This  include  mango,  (Mangifera  indica)  jackfruit,  (Artocarpus
heteroaphylla), coconut, Cocos nucifera Khoir (Treca catcha) bel (Aegel marmolos), etc. The area has
been disturbed by  agricultural activities for a  long  time  and there are no endangered  and  protected
species in the area.

9.
The  filling  materials  will  be  dredged  from  the  Turag/Buriganga  River.  The  riverbed  in  the
sections  around  Dhaka  has  been  polluted  from  untreated  domestic  and  industrial  wastewater
discharges.  The  benthic  communities  in  the  river  have  been  dislocated  for  a  long  time.  The  large
erosion  rate  and  subsequent  dredging  operations  to  maintain  the  transportation  and  flood  control
functions of the river has further disturbed the benthic communities.  There are about 260 species of
freshwater  fishes  recorded  for  the  whole  country.  Seasonal  variation  of  the  flooding  regime  has
marked variation on the ecology, biology, and behavior of the fish. The most common fish observed in
the  open  water  aquatic  habitat  are  rui,  cattla,  kalibush,  pabda,  pangas,  etc.  in  the  rivers;  and  koi,
magur, singh, sarputi, mola, tengra in the beels. Due to increasing pollution load and overexploitation
the  fisheries  resources  are  dwindling  very  fast.  In  the  closed  water  habitats  particularly  in  ponds,
some exotic fishes are reared including, silver carps, tilapia, panpsa, and Thai magur.

D.

Screening of Potential Environmental Impact and Mitigating Measures

10.
The  potential  environmental  impacts  of  the  expansion  of  the  substation  facilities  at  Tongi,
Kalyanpur, and Hasnabad are minor and reversible, as they mostly related to construction activities.
The  environmental  impacts  are  mostly  related  to  noise,  dust,  and  traffic  from  movement  of
construction materials, heavy equipment, and construction workers.

The filling operation for Aminbazar substation will reduce the size of the lagoon by 20 acres.
11.
The filling operation will increase the lagoon turbidity. The benthic communities in the 8-hectare area
will  be  destroyed.  This  is a  residual  impact  of  the  project.  Migratory  aquatic  life  will  migrate  and  be
displaced from this area. However as mentioned in para. 9, the aquatic life and flora have little or no

 Appendix 9, page 3

commercial value nor are they endangered or protected species. The construction activities after the
filling operation are similar to those in the other substations.

12.
The equipment  to  be  used  in the  substations  will  conform  to  existing  standards for  electrical
equipment and  will  not  contain  polychlorinated  biphenyl for  cooling  agent  in  transformers.  Asbestos
will not be used as an insulating agent.

13.
Noise from the transformers is low frequency noise and is damped by the perimeter walls. In
Tongi, Kalyanpur, and Hasnabad,  the noise from the factories  surrounding the  substation  is  several
magnitudes higher than those generated by the  transformers.  The noise  level  measured from those
areas varied from 62 to 77 decibels.

There are seven abandoned 230 kV towers right at the end of Tongi substation. These towers
14.
cannot be used as they are not designed for the type of conductor to be used for the Project. The line
route may, however, be used, and new towers may be installed near  the  locations  of  these  existing
abandoned towers. Inconvenience and disturbance may be felt by the residents during construction of
the transmission lines. For the 50  km stretch of the  transmission  line, few permanent  structures  will
have  to  be  relocated.   The  houses  will  be  relocated  in  adjacent  areas outside  the  transmission  line
right-of-way.  The  cultivators  will  be  allowed  to  cultivate  the  land  in  the  transmission  line of  right-of-
way as currently practiced, i.e., the flooded sections are cultivated only during the dry season.

15.
The  impact  of  the  Project  on  the  socioeconomic  conditions  of  the  service  area  is  primarily
positive. At present Dhaka City is experiencing frequent load-shedding up to six hours per day.  The
frequent fluctuation in power voltage has resulted in rapid deterioration of household appliances and
industrial machinery. Efficiencies in industries and commercial establishments have been affected by
load-shedding especially the small- and medium-scale industries that could not afford to buy their own
electric  generators.  Large  hotels  and  industries  buy  diesel-driven  electric  generators  often
secondhand  equipment.  The  secondhand  generators are often  polluting  with  low  electric-generating
efficiencies.

E.

Institutional Requirement and Environmental Monitoring

During  construction,  PGCB  will  appoint  an  environmental  and  safety  manager  who  will  be
16.
supported by three qualified engineers. The environmental and safety engineer will report directly to
the  project  director.  The  environmental  and  safety  engineer  will  be  responsible  for  monitoring  the
compliance of the Project to all safety and environmental requirements of the government as well as
the mitigating measures identified in the IEE report.

17.
During the  operation and  maintenance  of  the  Project,  PGCB  will  appoint  a  suitably  qualified
engineer  as  safety  and  environmental  officer  who  will  report  directly  to  the  managing  director.  The
environmental  and  safety  engineer  will  be  responsible  for  checking  that  the  workplace  procedures
comply with the environmental and safety standards of the industry as required by the  Government.
The environmental and safety engineer will be also the focal person in the  event  that  the Executing
Agency  applies  for  International  Standard  Organization  certification.  The  PGCB  will  submit  to  ADB
annually  a  copy  of  all  licenses  and  permits  required  by  the  relevant  agency  of  the  Government  for
environmental and safety regulations. In the event that the Project is cited for violation of any safety
and environmental standards within the reporting period, PGCB will submit to ADB a certification that
the defect has been corrected or an acceptable plan has been submitted to the relevant government
agency.

 Appendix 9, page 4

F.

Findings and Recommendations

18.
The project environmental  impact  is  minor  and temporary and  can  be  easily  mitigated  using
available technologies. The negative impacts of the Project are related to the  construction  activities.
The  main  residual  impacts  of  the  Project  are  related  to  the  filling  of  artificial  lagoon  in  Aminbazar
covering approximately 8  hectares and  resulting  in  the displacement  of  benthic ecology  in  this area
and  dislocation  of  some  aquatic  flora  and  fauna.  However,  the  aquatic  flora  and  fauna  are  not
endangered  or  protected  nor  do  they  have  commercial  value.  The  fill  materials  used  in  Aminbazar
substation are left over from the dredging of the rivers and channels in Dhaka. The land in Aminbazar
is basically a disposal area for the dredged materials.

G.

Conclusion

The  IEE  reveals no  significant adverse  impact  on  the  environment  that  cannot  be  mitigated.

19.
The preparation of a detailed environmental impact assessment is not deemed necessary.

 Appendix 10, page 1

SUMMARY LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT PLAN

A.

Background

The proposed Dhaka Power System Upgrade Project involves construction of substations,
1.
and transmission and distribution facilities in the Greater Dhaka Area.  Almost all land acquisition
and right of way activities will occur under Part A and affect a total of 2,000 square meters (m2) for
Kalyanpur substation, 20 acres of land for the Aminbazar substation, and 60  kilometers  (km)  of
right-of-way  for  the  transmission  facilities.  Part  B  and  Part  C  will  not  require  acquisition  of  land
except about 0.4 hectare of land for a new 132 kilovolt (kV) substation at Kamrangichar in Dhaka.
The land proposed to be acquired for Aminbazar substation is private land that floods each year
during  the  monsoon  and  therefore  does  not  support  any  permanent  residents  or  activities.  It  is
largely used as a source of "borrow" earth to fill other sites. However, it is possible that in the dry
season  some  of  this  land  may  be  used  for  temporary  shelters  or  marginal  farming.  The  main
impact of the project would occur during the stringing of the transmission lines. Possible impacts
could include damage to crops and displacement of persons although this would be only by about
ten  meters  in  each  case.  It  was  assessed  that  these  impacts  are  not  significant  and  can  be
mitigated  by  (i)  minimizing  such  impact  through  careful  routing  of  the  transmission  line,  and  (ii)
through  paying  adequate  compensation.  The  only  potentially  significant  impact  is  that  of
resettlement, which affects a maximum of about 100 persons, mostly migrant slum dwellers and
semipermanent residents. This number can be reduced significantly through a proper delineation
of the transmission lines. Compensation will be paid to all those affected.

B.

Good Practice

1.

Impact Minimization

2.

To minimize impact, the following guidelines for tower spotting will be observed:

(i)

(ii)

(iii)

(iv) 

(v)

The  alignment  will  avoid,  without  exception,  religious  structures,  and  educational
institutions.

As  far  as  may  be  practicable,  the  alignment  will  avoid  houses  (permanent  or
temporary).  In  particular,  special  care  will  be  taken  to  avoid  human  settlement
clusters. Where unavoidable, the ground clearance will be increased to at least 10
meters so that no resettlement is necessitated.

Where  road  and  river  crossing  is  unavoidable,  prescribed  vertical  and  horizontal
clearance requirements will be strictly adhered to.

The proposed alignment will be submitted on  a no-objection basis to (at least) the
following  Archaelogocial  Survey,  Wildlife  Conservation  Agency,  Inland  Water
Transport Authority, and Highway Department. These authorities will have 30 days
to formally object to the project.

Compensation  in  terms  of  country  and  ADB  norms  will  be  paid  to  owners  of  all
property, including crops, orchard trees, homesteads, water sources, etc., following
prescribed procedures.

2.

Resettlement Principles

Based on ADB Policy for Involuntary Resettlement, the following principles were  identified

3.
as being applicable for this activity for the Project:

 Appendix 10, page 2

(i)

(ii)

(iii)

(iv)

(v)

(vi)

(vii)

The  principal  objective  of  involuntary  settlement  policies  is  to  ensure  that
populations affected by the Project should be at  least as well off, if not better off
than  they  would  have  been  without  the  Project.  Affected  populations  should  be
able to maintain, and preferably improve their standard of living and quality of life.

The populations affected by the Project are defined as those who stand to lose, as
a  consequence  of  the  Project,  all  or  part  of  physical  and  nonphysical  assets,
including  homes,  homesteads,  productive  lands,  commercial  properties,  tenancy,
income-earning  opportunities,  social  and  cultural  activities  and  relationships,  and
other  losses  that  may  be  identified  during  the  process  of  resettlement  planning.
A preliminary socioeconomic survey was  carried  out  as  part  of  the  routing  of  the
transmission  line  and  the  findings  were  filed  with  the  deputy  office.  These  will
represent the cutoff date for  compensation  eligibility  for  physical  assets  as  these
were  identified.  Affected populations  will  receive  fair  (market-based  replacement
cost)  compensation  for  all  losses,  including  physical  and  nonphysical  assets.
Compensation  will  include  not  only  immediate  losses,  but  also  opportunities
foregone. Affected populations who stand to lose only part of their physical assets
will  not  be  left  with  a  proportion  inadequate  to  sustain  their  current  standard  of
living,  such  a  minimum  was  identified  and  agreed  to  during  the  resettlement
planning process.

All  affected  populations  will  be  equally  eligible  for  compensation  and  mitigative
measures,  irrespective  of  tenurial  status,  social  or  economic  standing,  and  any
such factors that may discriminate against achieving the objectives outlined.

Involuntary resettlement will be minimized by identifying possible alternative project
designs; and appropriate social, economic, operational, and engineering solutions
that have the  least  impact on populations  in  the project area. As  it  is  possible  to
identify the affected population only during the actual stringing of the transmission
lines, a  short  resettlement  plan  will  be  prepared  for  the  affected  populations  and
specifying  those  affected,  all  losses  that  might  be  incurred,  and  appropriate
mitigative measures.

Adequate  budgetary  support  will  be  fully  committed  and  be  made  available
to cover  the  costs  of  land  acquisition  within  the  agreed  implementation  period.
The project  performa  prepared  by  Power  Grid  Company  of  Bangladesh
Ltd. For the Hasnabad-Aminbazar  (Savar)-Tongi  and  the  Haripur-Meghnaghat
230kV transmission line contains two cost items for this purpose.  An allocation of
Tk3.88  million for  right-of-way payments and of Tk129  million  for  land  acquisition
for substations is included on page 15, item 1 (c) of the project performa budget.

Construction activities will not commence until the required  lands have been fully
acquired and populations appropriately relocated in accordance with the principles
set out.

Appropriate  reporting,  monitoring,  and  evaluation  mechanisms  will  be  identified
and set in place as part of the resettlement management system.  Evaluation of the
resettlement process and the final outcome  will be  conducted  independent of the
Executing Agency.

The  current  legislation governing  land acquisition for  public purposes  in  Bangladesh  is
4.
the Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance (Ordinance II of 1982) and its
subsequent  amendments  in  1993  and  1994.  In  accordance  with  the  ordinance,  the  legal
process  is  initiated  by  an  application  by  the  requiring  agency  or  department  to  the  deputy

 Appendix 10, page 3

commissioner  of  the  district.  In  determining  the  amount  of  compensation  for  the  affected
owners,  the  deputy  commissioner  takes  into  consideration  a  number  of  factors,  e.g.,  present
market rate to determine the value of the land. As there is no national policy for resettlement of
project-affected people  in  Bangladesh,  ADB  Policy  on Involuntary  Resettlement  will  guide  the
resettlement plan.

C.

Project Compensation Policy and Entitlement Matrix

5.
The  project  compensation  policy  and  entitlement  matrix  was  designed  to  cover
compensation  for  lost  assets  and  restore  or  enhance  the  livelihoods  of  all  categories  (direct,
indirect, title holders, and nontitle-holders) of affected people. The affected persons will not only
receive  replacement  land  or  cash  for  land  and  other  assets  at  market  price,  many  additional
measures will be taken, e.g. moving allowance, assistance to household headed by women, to
help the project-affected persons to regain or improve their lives in the postresettlement period.

The cost of ordinary capital resources debt was calculated based on an interest rate of
7 percent per annum, a local markup of 1 percent per annum, an income tax rate of 40 percent
per annum, and an international inflation rate of 2.4 percent per annum. On this basis, and using
an  average  outstanding  loan  balance  per  annum  over  the  life  of  the  loan,  the  cost  of  foreign
debt, in real terms was computed to be 2.4 percent.

 Appendix 12, page 3

The  cost  of  Special  Funds  resources  was  calculated  based  on  an  interest  rate  of
5.
1.5 percent  per  annum,  a  local  markup  of  6.5  percent  per  annum,  an  income  tax  rate  of
40 percent  per  annum,  and  an  international  inflation  rate  of  2.4  percent  per  annum.  On  this
basis, and using an average outstanding loan balance per annum over the life of the loan, the
cost of foreign debt, in real terms was computed to be 2.4 percent.

6.
The  cost  of  Government  debt  for  parts  A,  B(ii),  and  B(iii)  was  calculated  based  on  an
interest  rate  of  8  percent  per  annum,  an  income  tax  rate  of  40  percent  per  annum,  and  an
average domestic inflation rate of 4.5 percent per annum. On this basis, and using an average
outstanding loan balance per annum over the life of the loan, the cost of  Government  debt,  in
real terms, was computed to be less than 1 percent.

The  cost  of  Government  debt  for  B(i)  was  calculated  based  on  an  interest  rate  of
7.
3 percent per annum and an average domestic inflation rate of 4.5 percent per annum. On this
basis, and using an average outstanding loan balance per annum over the life of the loan, the
cost of Government debt, in real terms was computed to be less than 1 percent.

8.
The  opportunity  cost  of  equity  in  Bangladesh,  in  real  terms,  was  been  calculated  as
follows  on  the  basis  of  current  long-term  savings  rates  adjusted  by  adding  a  risk  premium  of
3 percent per annum and taking into account the effect of average domestic inflation at a rate of
4.5 percent per annum.

Based  upon  the  above,  the  following  WACCs  have  been  computed:  Part  A,

9.
4.52 percent; Part B(i), 0.28 percent; Part B(ii), 4.68 percent; and Part B(iii), 4.36 percent.

D.

Conclusion

10.
For  each project  component,  the  FIRR  is  expect to  comfortably  exceed  the WACC  for
that  component  (both  computed  on  an  after-tax  basis).  Given  the  overall  objectives  of  the
Project, the financial performance is deemed acceptable.

 Appendix 13, page 1

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS

1.
An economic evaluation for the entire Project consisting of transmission and distribution
investments  was  undertaken,  and  the  results  are  summarized  here.  Details  of  the  economic
internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  calculations  are  shown  in  Table  A13.3,  results  of  the  switching
value analysis are in Table A13.1, and the findings of the sensitivity analysis are given in Table
A13.2.

2.
As the Project is specifically targeting the greater Dhaka area, there are only three major
consumer  segments,  domestic,  commercial,  and  industrial,  for  which  economic  benefits  were
calculated.  For each of the 13 distribution circles included in the Project the incremental power
supply was calculated and the breakdown for each consumer segment was analyzed. Economic
benefits were then calculated separately for each distribution circle and consumer segment.

3.
The shares of electricity supply assumed to replace an alternative energy source in each
consumer category  were  based  on existing  load-shedding data  in each distribution  circle.  It  is
assumed that over a period of four years load-shedding will be eliminated in all circles covered
under the Project. New consumers will also be connected to the grid in each distribution circle
over a four-year period. Their consumption in the first year after being connected to the grid is
considered  to  replace other fuels and  to  result  in economic  resource  cost  saving.  That  is,  the
economic cost of alternative energy, which the country saves by using electricity, is considered
an economic benefit of the Project.

The  shares of  incremental electricity  supply  corresponding  to  induced  consumption  for
4.
newly connected consumers are assumed to grow rapidly for four years before normalizing. The
assumed annual growth rates are 10, 15,13, and 10 percent before settling to normal growth at
5  percent  per  annum.  Induced  consumption  was  valued  by  estimating  the  consumer’s
willingness to pay for this part of incremental electricity supply. Given the sensitivity of demand
to  price  for  the  various  categories  of  consumers,  only  a  portion  of  the  maximum  consumer’s
surplus benefits  is assumed for the valuation of induced sales.

Alternative  sources  of  power  used  by  the  three  major  consumer  segments  were
5.
determined, and their respective costs were estimated. It was found that the dominant sources
of alternative power in the domestic sector are kerosene lamps and inverter batteries.  Private
ownership  of  small-sized  diesel  generators  is  very  low  and  prevailing  only  among  very  high-
income  urban  consumers,  and  can  thus  not  be  considered  for  the  purpose  of  estimating  the
willingness-to-pay. A  large proportion of total end-consumption  in the  domestic  sector  is  used
for lighting purposes and to run small appliances like televisions, fans and radios. During power
cuts, substitution  of electricity  is almost  exclusively for  lighting purposes.  Therefore, economic
benefits for the replacement portion of alternative energy sources were valued at an economic
cost  of  kerosene  lamps  at  Tk5.2  per  kilowatt  hour  (kWh).  Induced  consumption  was  valued
using the willingness-to-pay method plus the related consumer surplus with a curvature factor of
0.3.  However,  the  calculation  was  based  on  the  use  of  inverter  batteries  as  the  alternative
energy source as induced consumption is more  likely used for  small appliances.  The financial
cost of using inverter batteries was estimated at Tk3.6 per kWh.

Commercial sector use of alternative sources is represented by a  mixture  of  small and
6.
lamps.  To
medium-size  generators  and 
accommodate the difference in use, two sizes of generators are included in the calculation. The
consumption  share  of  the  commercial  sector  was  divided  equally  between  2  and  5  kW

for  very  small  establishments  of  kerosene 

 Appendix 13, page 2

generators for the calculation of benefits. Average economic cost of alternative energy sources
for  commercial  establishments  has  been  estimated  at  Tk8.81  for  a  2  kW  generator  and  at
Tk5.28 for a 5 kW generator. A curvature factor of 0.4 was used in the calculations.

7.
As  a  result  of  the  persistent  power  shortages  in  Bangladesh  the  industry  sector  has
installed  a  large  number  of  alternative  sources  of  energy.  Officially,  400  megawatts  (MW)  of
private generation capacity exist in the country, which corresponds to about a fifth of the public
power plants currently operating.1 Captive power facilities cover a wide range of unit sizes and
plant  types  with  the  most  dominant  being  large  diesel  generator  sets.  The  average  cost
depends on the size of the generator and was estimated to lie between Tk5.25  per  kWh for a
240 kW generator and Tk5.5 per kWh for a 500kW generator.  As for the commercial segment,
a curvature factor of 0.4 was used.

8.
For  the  purposes  of  the  economic  analysis,  the  estimated  capital  costs  of  the
transmission and distribution components have been broken down into direct foreign exchange
items, indirect foreign  exchange,  and  local goods  and  services.  All  costs  elements are  valued
in border  prices,  using  a  domestic  currency  numeraire,  with  all  taxes  and  duties  excluded.
A standard  conversion  factor  of  0.855  is  applied  to  nontraded  items  and  a  labor  conversion
factor  of  0.9  is  used.  Operating  costs  were  calculated  as  a  fixed  percentage  of  economic
investment  cost.  For  the  transmission  component  this  percentage  is  kept  constant  over  the
evaluation  period,  while  for  the  distribution  component  it  is  assumed  that  after  five  years  of
operation the percentage is increased to reflect higher maintenance needs.

The  economic  benefits  of  transmission  and  distribution  facilities  required  to  evacuate
9.
power  from  new  generation  projects,  such  as  Haripur  IPP,  are  difficult  to  determine
independently.  Transmission  and  distribution  are  integral  parts  of  the  total  power  system
development  plan  and  not  independent  investments.  The  EIRR  on  the  complete  investment
required in new generation projects plus associated transmission and distribution are normally
considered as representative of the rate of return on transmission and distribution investments,
as they are typically only a part of the total investment.

Therefore,  the  economic  evaluations  of  transmission  and  distribution  components
10.
include  economic  sent-out  costs  of  power.  The  Project  specifically  targets  constructing
transmission  and  distribution  facilities  needed  to  evacuate  power  from  the  newly  solicited
independent  power  producers  for  about  1,400  MW  of  generating  capacity.  A  number  of  IPP
agreements  have  been  concluded  among  them  are  independent  power  producers  for  about
400 MW  from  barge-mounted  plants  of  which  100  MW  is  already  being  produced.  Another
890 MW, including the Meghnaghat and Haripur plants  have almost  reached financial  closure.
Latest calculations of the long-run marginal cost (LRMC), which took into account the IPPs sent-
out costs, show that the current LRMC in Bangladesh is about 30 per cent below its 1994 level.
This can mainly be attributed to lower unit investment costs and the higher fuel efficiency of new
gas  plants.  Also,  the  economic  cost  of  gas  declined  based  on  the  actual  costs  incurred  in
developing new gas fields. Consequently, the bid prices for  sent-out energy  received from  the
first  IPPs  were  unexpectedly  low,  although  higher  than  actual  gas  prices  have  already  been
assumed  in  the  IPPs.  However,  to  be  more  conservative,  the  economic  evaluation  used  the
weighted average of IPP sent-out cost instead of the recalculated LRMC.

                                               
1 According to the World Bank  1998, Energy Strategy Note.

 Appendix 13, page 3

On  the  basis  of  a  comparison  of  economic  costs  and  benefits  over  a  20-year  project
11.
lifetime, including a four-year construction period, the economic  internal  rate  of  returns  (EIRR)
was estimated at 22.7 percent with a net present value (NPV) of TK3,330 million.

 OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR  THE SOCIAL SURVEY

Appendix 14, page 1

A. 

Introduction

B. 

Scope of Work

1.
Assessment of the socioeconomic impact of electrification is essential to gauge whether
overarching poverty reduction goals of electrification are being met. Thus, in the context of the
Bank's  Dhaka  Power  System  Upgrade  Project,  the  Bank  is  attempting  to  quantitatively  and
qualitatively  assess  the  socioeconomic  benefits  of  electrification,  and  improved  electricity
supply, in the Greater Dhaka Area with a special emphasis on the urban poor.

2.
The  consultants  will  determine  through  surveys,  interviews,  and  scrutiny  of  existing
records,  the  (i)  actual  energy  expenditures  in  electrified  and  nonelectrified  households  for
comparable  energy  outputs;  (ii)  impact  of  electrification  on  productive  activities;  (iii)  impact  of
electrification  on  household  income  and  household  expenditures,  education,  and  social
activities; (iv) impact of  electrification  on  public service  institutions to  include hospitals,  clinics,
schools, and  related  delivery  agencies;  and  (v)  impact  of  electrification  on  small  and  medium
enterprises (SME).

3.

Tasks to be carried out by the consultants will include but not be limited to:

(i) 

(ii) 
(iii) 
(iv) 
(v) 

(vi) 
(vii) 

selecting sample households reflecting different income levels, income sources,
electrified and nonelectrified households, and households with cottage industries
and without;
selecting sample public service institutions and SMEs;
designing the questionnaires;
conducting interviews;
cross-checking results with area officials, community leaders, and retailers (for
cost indications);
analyzing and evaluating the collected data; and
preparing the final report

C. 

Outline Terms of Reference

Three  different  consumer  categories  are  included  under  the  study:  households,  public

service institutions, and SMEs. For each of the categories, the specific link to electrification will
be established and WTP/ATP will be determined, as follows:

a.

does it relate to energy consumption?
Is there a link between electrification and higher profit (higher income)?
How does electrification relate to education, medical services, information, etc.?

attention should  be  paid  to  gender  differentiation  in  energy  use,  in  particular  in
cottage industries.
Determine length of use per source and the cost per use per source.

this;

Public Service Institutions

and client benefit?

affordability and willingness to pay; and
recommendations, as relevant, for how increased costs will be met.

Micro and Small Enterprises

The  study  will  establish  a  link  between  provision  of  reliable  electricity  services  and

expansion of SME business turnover and employment, e.g.:

(ii) 
(iii)

context of their contribution to the economy.
Identify how current energy requirements and energy costs are met;
Determine if the availability of energy is linked to production and profit.

Outline the future requirements for energy and how will this contribute to greater
efficiency and expansion of the sector, including additional employment.
